texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 24-year-old Saada S. from Mwanza. She is married with one child, aged seven. Saada has been running a maize business since 2006. Client's business is selling maize. She works at the business for twelve hours per day, six days per week and is assisted by three employees. Saada currently earns about 200usd from her business. She is requesting a loan of 350usd in order to buy more maize. In the future, she plans to increase the stock quantity. Saada thanks you for her support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To buy more maize

loans.name: Shafika

texts.en: Shafika is a very ambitious woman of 39 years who owns a small shop selling candies and other treats in the Southern Lebanese city of Saida. Shafika has requested a $1000 loan to help her pay for an urgent surgicA. procedure. If there is money left over from the loan, she plans to use it to purchase new inventory for her shop. This will be the third loan Shafika has taken from A. Majmoua. Shafika is very grateful for Kiva and all who give her the chance to have this surgery and improve her business.

loans.use: to pay for an urgent surgical procedure

loans.name: Nyanama Twegatte Group

texts.en:
Immaculate N. is the leader of Nyanama Twegatte group. This is the second time she is seeking a loan from Kiva to boost her business selling matooke. She is very grateful for the help rendered to her group.

With time, Immaculate has been able to expand her business to sell a variety of produce to her stall. She plans to use this loan to buy more bunches of matooke, sweet potatoes, cassava, and Irish potatoes for her business in order to earn more profits.

As a widow, she is the bread-winner of the family. But with the profits from her business and part of her savings, she's been able to cater for her children and caretakers.

loans.use: To buy more produce to sell in her stall.

loans.name: Pen

texts.en:
Pen C., 38, is married and resides with her husband in the Siem Reap province of Cambodia. This couple together has two young school-aged children.  Since 2005, she has been selling fish at the market to earn a living and is able to make $5 of profit a day. She often receives fish from her husband, who works as a fisherman. He gives his catch to his wife and the rest he sells to other fish sellers in the market. On average, he makes $4 of profit a day. 
Pen C. spends $50 on food every month, $17 on utilities and $20 on children’s education. 

Pen C. would like to take out a loan of $500 to purchase more fishing tools for her husband. This will allow her husband to catch more fish.

loans.use: To purchase more fishing tools.

loans.name: Umoja Charambe Group

texts.en:
Mlokozi M., 36, is married with three children ages 9, 5, and 1. He sells second-hand clothes. He started this business in 2000 and works daily from 8:30 am until 6 pm. He is able to earn a monthly profit of around US$ 80.

This will be Mlokozi’s seventh’s loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. He used the previous loans to increase the stock of his second-hand clothes business and has repaid the loans successfully. He now hopes for a seventh loan to buy more stock for the same business.

Mlokozi will share this loan with his loan group, Umoja Charambe, which totals 15 members. The members of the group hold each other accountable in paying back their loans. In the picture, Mlokozi is standing 1st from the left.

loans.use: To increase his stock of used clothes for re-sale

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en: Lydia K. is thirty-six years old. She is married and has given birth to three children, a girl and two sons. She says two of her children are in school at the moment. The other one is yet to start school. Lydia’s husband is a commercial driver. She lives with her family in a rented apartment at Offinso in the Ashanti region of Ghana. Offinso is a business/farming community. Lydia trades in fresh fish. She procures fresh fish from big cold store operators in the nearby cities at wholesale prices. She sells the fresh fish on a table in the local market square. She distributes mostly to food vendors in her community. Lydia has been in business for over ten years. She wants a loan to buy fresh fish in bulk to be able to supply more customers. She desires to acquire refrigerators to store some of the fresh fish she procures. She hopes to help her husband to put up a building of their own.

loans.use: To procure fresh fish

loans.name: Luz

texts.es: Luz es una joven de 19 años, muy alegre y conversadora, vive en la casa de sus padres, a los cuales ayuda en los gastos del hogar y aunque es muy joven, ya sabe lo que es trabajar arduamente. Ella vende ropa en el centro de Puno, tiene una tienda alquilada donde ofrece sus novedosos y bellos vestidos, los cuales son muy solicitados por las jovencitas, sobre todo para asistir a sus bailes de promoción del colegio. Lleva dos años en este negocio, en los cuales ha alivianado la carga económica de su familia, lo que más le gusta de su trabajo es aconsejar a las jovencitas que viene a comprar vestidos, siempre les dice cual les queda mejor o cual combina con su color de piel, es una buena vendedora y espera tener una tienda más grande donde no solo venda vestidos, si no también ropa casual, lo que menos le gusta de su trabajo es tener que permanecer mucho tiempo en su tienda sin poder salir. Es el segundo préstamo de Luz con MFP, y a su corta edad sabe que tiene que pagarlo y no fallar en sus cuotas, en su banco comunal es muy querida, ya que es la más joven y alegre. Los mil nuevos soles que solicita los invertirá en incrementar la mercadería de su tienda y comprar más vestidos.
texts.en:
Luz is a very happy and conservative 19 year old. She lives with her parents, whom she helps with household expenses. Although she is very young, she already knows what it means to work hard. She sells clothing in downtown Puno: she rents a shop where she sells her original, beautiful dresses, which are in high demand among young women, in particular for wearing to school graduation dances. Luz has two years of experience in this business, during which time she has lessened her family's financial burden. The thing she likes most about her job is giving advice to the young women who come to buy dresses. She always tells them which dresses suit them most, or which ones go best with their skin tones. She is a good saleswoman and hopes to have a larger shop where she can sell not only dresses, but also casual clothing. The thing she likes least about her job is having to stay at the shop for long periods of time. This is Luz's second loan with [kiva.org partner] Microfinanzas Prisma and, even at her young age, she already understands she must repay the loan and not fall behind on her payments. She is well liked in her community bank, seeing she is the youngest and happiest member. The 1,000 nuevos soles [about US$ 325] she is requesting will be used to expand the merchandise available in her shop and to purchase more dresses.

Translated from Spanish by Todd M. Anderson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Expansion of merchandise

loans.name: Kokou

texts.fr: Agé de 35 ans, Mr Kokou A. est un cultivateur et a, à sa charge, six (06) enfants. Il a bénéficié d’un premier crédit pour la culture de la banane qui a été dévastée par les précédentes inondations qu’a connu le Togo lors de la saison pluvieuse passée. Aujourd’hui il souhaite se lancer dans la culture du mais à grande échelle et sollicite pour cela un financement. Le financement de ce projet contribuera largement à changer positivement sa vie et celle de sa famille sur le plan social et économique.
texts.en:
Mr Kokou A., age 35, is a farmer who has 6 children to support. He obtained a first loan for his banana plantation that got destroyed by the floods that occurred in Togo during the latest wet season. He now wishes to start a large-scale corn growing business, which is why he is seeking a loan. Getting this loan will greatly contribute to changing his life, and those of his family, in a positive manner on the social and economic fronts.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Corn growing

loans.name: Argelia

texts.es: La señora Argelia vive con su esposo el señor Isaidel y tienen una niña; ella tiene un pequeño negocio D. venta D. nachos con queso, fritos con queso, paletas D. hielo, etc. Y su esposo trabaja para una empresa con un buen ingreso desD. hace una año, el esta apoyando a su esposa en solicitar este crédito para la compra D.  mercancía para su negocio.
texts.en:
Argelia lives with her husband, Isaidel, and they have one daughter. She has a small business selling nachos with cheese, cheese fries, frozen ice pops, etc. Her husband has worked at an enterprise for one year, earning a good income. He is supporting his wife in this loan request, for the purchase of merchandise for her business.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To invest in her business.

loans.name: Dopé

texts.fr: Akakpo drah a commencé depuis 2005 le commerce en gros d’eau en sachet« pure water », des sacs de riz et des bidons d’huile. Ce commerce lui réussit bien et elle a beaucoup de clientèle. Son stock actuel ne lui permet pas de bien satisfaire ses clients. Elle a déjà obtenu de WAGES un crédit qu’elle a remboursé. Elle demande un deuxième crédit pour acheter 20 cartons VOLTIC, 100 sachets VOLTIC, 25 cartons VITAL, 100 sachet VITAL, 06 sacs de riz et 05 bidons d’huile. Elle est mariée à un monsieur qui est fonctionnaire d’état et à 02 enfants qui font  l’école primaire.
texts.en:
A. began a business in 2005 selling, on a wholesale basis, bags of drinking water of the brand «pure water», sacks of rice and jerrycans of oil. This business is going well and she has lots of customers. Her present stock does not permit her to satisfy her customers' needs. She has already had one loan from WAGES and has reimbursed it correctly. She is requesting her second loan to buy 20 cases of VOLTIC, 100 bags of VOLTIC, 25 cases of VITAL, 100 bags of VITAL, 6 sacks of rice, and 5 jerrycans of oil. She is married to a gentleman who is a civil servant and has two children who are in primary school.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of bags of drinking water, VOLTIC, sacks of rice and jerrycans of oil

loans.name: Lucia

texts.es:
La señora Lucia  es socia del Banco Manuela Ramos  del Distrito D. Mazocruz, Provincia del Collao, Departamento D. Puno; tiene 51 años D. edad, D. estado civil conviviente tiene 3 hijos propios y 7 adoptivos hijos, vive en el Barrio 3 D. Mayo Jr. 28 D. Julio y cuenta con estudios D. 3ro D. segundaria.

La señora viene trabajando con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos desD. hace 10 años  e inició su préstamo con la suma D. 300.00 Nuevos Soles, el cual le permitió incrementar su negocio D. compra y venta D. carne.
En la actualidad requiere D. un nuevo préstamo, el cual solicitará por el monto D. 3000.00 Nuevos Soles, el cual le permitirá comprar mayor cantidad D. D. carne.
Su mayor deseo es comprarse un carro para transportar su mercadería. Lo que más le gusta D. su  Banco Comunal es el cumplimiento D. las demás socias.
texts.en:
Mrs. Lucia is a member of Bank Manuela Ramos at the Mazocruz district, Province of Collao, Department of Puno; she is 51 years old, and lives with her partner, she has 3 children of her own and 7 adopted children, lives in the neighborhood of 3 D. Mayo Jr. 28 D. Julio, she didn't finished high school. Mrs. Lucia has been working with Manuela Ramos for the past 10 years, her first loan was for 300 new Soles, which helped her increase her business of buying and selling meat. Currently she wants a new loan for 3000 New Soles to buy larger quantities of meat. Her biggest wish is to buy a car so she can transport her merchandise. What she likes most about the community bank is the fulfillment of payment by all members.

Translated from Spanish by Nina Delgado, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy meat

loans.name: Heidy Thalia

texts.es:
HEIDY THALIA V. V., pertenece al Banco Comunal “LORETO” vive en el Jr comandante suares Nº 620, en la ciudad de Pucallpa, tiene 28 años de edad, 02 hermosos hijos menores de edad y su esposo trabaja en un aserradero.

Ella y su madre trabajan juntas en el negocio de comidas tìpicas  por las tardes y noches, venden juanes, tacacho, y pescado asado y con el primer préstamo de S/.300.00 Nuevos Soles, se implemento con una parrilla, e insumos, como vive en una zona bien concurrida el negocio le ha salido muy bien.

La buena atención que la caracteriza ha hecho que tenga muchos clientes y ha sido necesario incrementar su capital.  Con este préstamo  de S/.1,000.00 Nuevos Soles, invertirá en ampliar su negocio, comprará mesas, sillas e insumos para la elaboración de sus platos.  Asì mismo hará arreglos en su local.

Dice que Manuela Ramos es la institución que confía en ella y el negocio que tiene le permite costear los gastos del colegio de sus hijos, además de su casa.
texts.en:
Heidy Thalia V. V. belongs to the "Loreto" Communal Bank. She lives in the city of Pucallpa. She is 28 years old, has two beautiful young children, and her husband works in a sawmill. She and her mother work together in a restaurant during afternoons and evenings. They sell juanes (a local rice and meat dish cooked in a banana leaf), tacaho (grilled plantain) and grilled fish. With the first loan of 300 soles, she started with a grill and inputs. As she lives in a busy business area, her business has gone well. The good service she provides has brought in many customers, and she needs to increase her capital. With this loan of 1,000 soles, she will expand her business, and purchase tables, chairs and ingredients to make her dishes. She will also make repairs to her space. She says that Manuela Ramos is the institution that believed in her and her business, and allowed her to cover the costs of her children's education and her home.

Translated from Spanish by Trisha Bury, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase tables, chairs and inputs

loans.name: Marissa

texts.en:
Marissa P. is from the town of Lopez Jaena, Misamis Occidental. She is 38 years old, married and has three school-age children. To make a living, Marissa owns and operates a specialized retail store selling clothing, cosmetics and shoe products in her community. Marissa has been in this business for over two years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month.

In 2002, Marissa joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Marissa has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. Marissa is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offerings and for house renovation. This will be her ninth loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue to make improvements to her house.

About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand product offering and for house renovation

loans.name: African Child Group

texts.en:
Hawa S. has been eight years in the sale of dry goods (slippers, blouses, T-shirts, etc.) in the Duala market in the Bushrod Island community. She has never gone to school but has four children whose age ranges between 4 and 14 years.

With her business, Hawa is able to care for all of her children, send them to school, pay for medical attention, and provide good food as well as owning a house. Her business goal is to have an improved business to help the family through.

loans.use: To buy slippers, T-shirts, blouses, pants, underwear, etc.

loans.name: Rafaela

texts.es:
La señora Rafaela, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Molino-Juli”  que esta ubicado en el Centro Poblado de Molino, del distrito de Juli, Provincia de Chucuito, Departamento de Puno, ella tiene 49 años de edad, de estado civil conviviente, es madre de 05 hijos y tiene estudios de primaria incompleta, vive en la comunidad de Sihuiro Sector Tishua.

Trabaja con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos desde hace casi 3 años, su préstamo inicial fue de S/. 300.00 nuevos soles, el cual utilizó para la compra de chifleria (productos varios). 

En este momento ella requiere un préstamo de S/. 500.00 Nuevos soles, para la compra de betunes, pasta dental, escobillas de zapato, ganchos de ropa, detergentes, etc. Solo vende en las ferias de Ilave.  Los demás días se dedica a las pesca, 

Su deseo es poder criar ganado para engorde.

A ella le gustan los ahorros en su Banco Comunal.
texts.en:
Ms. P. is a member of the “Molino-Juli” Microfinance Institute, located in Molino, in the Juli district of the Chucuito province, department of Puno. She is a 49-year-old woman with a live-in partner and 5 children. She completed elementary school, and lives in the Tishua sector of the community of Sihuiro.

She has been working with the Manuela Ramos Movement for almost 3 years. She used her first loan—in the amount of 300.00 PEN—to purchase miscellaneous items.

At this time, she needs a 500.00 PEN loan in order to purchase shoe polish, shoe brushes, toothpaste, clothes hangers, detergent, etc. She only sells her products in the street markets of Ilave. She makes a living by fishing the rest of the week.

Her wish is to raise livestock.

She likes the savings that she obtains through her microfinance institute.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase items

loans.name: Silvia Irene

texts.es:
La señora Silvia C. se ha destacado por ser una vendedora de verduras y especies en el departamento de León donde tiene su propio negocio.

A diario ofrece sus productos con el fin de llevar el sustento a su hogar de habitación y así beneficiar a su familia con el mantenimiento. El motivo por el que ha acudido a Ceprodel es para solicitar el crédito para la compra de las verduras tales como los tomates, cebollas y repollos e igual con la compra de todo tipo de especies para ofrecerlas en su establecimiento.
texts.en:
Señora Silvia C. is known as a saleswoman of vegetables and spices in the department of León where she has her own business. Daily she offers her products in order to make a living for her household and thus to maintain her family. Her motive for approaching Ceprodel is to request a loan for the purchase of vegetables such as tomatoes, onions and cabbages and also to purchase all kinds of spices to offer them in her establishment.

Translated from Spanish by Barbara (B) Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy vegetables and spices for resale.

loans.name: Liza

texts.en: Liza M. is from the village of Lopez Jaena. She is 37 years old, is married, and has eight school-aged children. Liza owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month. In 2008, Liza joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Liza is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and used as working capital. This loan will be her 3rd from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and to use as working capital

loans.name: Baatarsuren

texts.en: Baatarsuren is a 46-year-old carpenter who lives with his wife and two college-student children in Uvurkhangai province in central Mongolia. He started a carpentry business in 1996 along with his wife. In their business, he does the carpentry work while she paints the products. They produce wooden parts of ger (nomadic housing tent) and its furniture. Since the business is his main source of income, his biggest priority is providing high quality products.  They live in their own house that he inherited from his parents. His ultimate goal is to make sure their children receive a good education and become good people. Baatarsuren requests a loan of 600,000 Tugrugs to purchase more timber to make more durable and high quality products.

loans.use: To purchase more timber

loans.name: Vivine

texts.en:
Vivine N. is 42 years old, married with 8 children aged between 15 and 4.

Vivine has an experience of 3 years in having a shop in which she sells various products. She starts shopping from 8h00 A.M to 8h00 P.M. Vivine is requesting her first loan from Vision Finance Company s.a   for the purpose of expanding her business through purchasing more foodstuff.

By requesting and using this loan, Vivine plans to help her husband through the profit to buy a house and get more food for her family.

loans.use: purchasing more foodstuff for sale

loans.name: Las Colorinas Group

texts.es: El banco “Las Colorinas” esta representado por la señora Susana y conformado por 13 socias (os), D. los cuales 11 son mujeres y 2 son varones, muy trabajadores, responsables y cumplidos como lo han demostrado en sus anteriores ciclos. Las socias en su mayoría se dedican al comercio D. diferentes productos como  ropa, comestibles, lácteos, venta D. gafas, atención en salón D. belleza, venta D. relojes entre otros. En cuanto a la competencia el entorno donD. se desarrollan las actividades cuenta con demanda D. consumidores ya que la zona es comercial y no tienen mucha dificultar para su venta. El crédito otorgado esta destinado al incremento del capital D. trabajo y crecimiento D. los negocios, el banco se conformo con socias que ya cuentan con experiencia D. trabajo en créditos solidarios y dan gracias por el apoyo económico brindado por la Fundación Agrocapital ya que gracias a ello pueden darle a sus familias una mejor educación y un mejor hogar para vivir.

loans.use: Capital de Operaciones

loans.name: Granito De Oro Group

texts.es: Granito de oro es un grupo de 9 mujeres y un varón, todos son   alegres, amables y carismáticos,  actualmente están en el ciclo 2 y se agruparon por la necesidad de contar con un capital que les permita ampliar sus negocios, una de las integrantes es Merced Lucy M. con 27 años. Es madre de un niño, ella tiene el negocio de venta de ropa de lana de alpaca, inicialmente ella era vendedora pero con la ayuda de su madre logró poner una tienda propia, actualmente necesita el préstamo para la compra de chompa de lana de alpaca, sus principales clientes son los turistas. Las demás integrantes también tienen sus propios negocios como la venta de dulces, zapatos ropas, cosméticos y comida y necesitan el préstamo para comprar mercadería o insumos.
texts.en:
Granito de Oro is a group consisting of nine women and one man, all cheery, amiable and charismatic people. Currently they are in their second loan cycle and they became a group so they could take advantage of capital that would allow them to grow their businesses. One of the members, Lucy M., is 27 years old and mother of one. Her business is selling clothing made out of alpaca wool. Originally she was a salesperson, but with her mother’s help she opened her own store. Currently she needs the loan to purchase alpaca sweaters. Her main customers are tourists. The other members of the group have different businesses, such as selling sweets, shoes, clothing, cosmetics and food, and they need the loan to purchase merchandise.

Translated from Spanish by Maya Wisnievitz, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of merchandise

loans.name: Christ Capable Group

texts.en:
The “Christ Capable” or “Christ is Able” Group consists of fifteen male and female entrepreneurs. After successfully repaying their 1st and 2nd loans, they are looking forward to continued success and growth in their businesses with their 3rd loan. Wideline M. is one of three representatives of the group. She is married with five young children ranging in age from 3 months to 9 yrs old.

This hardworking mom sells a variety of fresh foods including rice, beans, vegetables, dried fish and oils for cooking. She sells both in the local market and at a small stand in front of her home. Wideline is thankful for the loan because it has allowed her to provide a better life for her children.

Wideline dreams of doing great things with her business to be able to give her family a brighter future. On behalf of Wideline, Christ Capable and Esperanza we thank you for your support.

loans.use: To buy more fresh foods including rice, beans, vegetables, dried fish and oils for cooking

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en: Margaret is 51 years old and married with 8 children. She sells provisions close to her home and is excited to receive a Kiva loan of 140, 000 to purchase more provisions to sell. She hopes that this loan will help her build a business that will be profitable and provide benefits for her family. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions to sell

loans.name: Ny

texts.en: Mrs. Ny N. is 29 years old and she lives in Tuol Kandal village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a 2.8-hectare field of land on which she grows rice. She faces an obstacle because her field has infertile soil. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizers and pesticides, and to hire laborers to work on the field. Mrs. Ny N. has a child who is too young to work or study.

loans.use: Farm supplies and payroll

loans.name: Alma

texts.en:
Alma P., age 31, dreams of a better life for her family. She is working so hard to improve her harvest and support her family. Alma started to till her rice farm in 1996. She says that her farm needs capital, especially to buy seeds and pay for labor.

She is asking for a loan of Php 8,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy farm supplies so she can have an abundant harvest and more income.

loans.use: Farm Supplies

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional ingredients for her business.

loans.name: José León

texts.es:
José León G. F., tiene la edad de 70 años, está  soltero. El crédito lo quiere para la compra de abono y fertilizantes para dar asistencia  a una plantación de café que posee. El desea darle el adecuado mantenimiento al cultivo  para  que este le permita  tener una mayor producción y así tener mayores ingresos económicos. No es la primera vez que realiza un crédito con FUDECOSUR y está muy contento con las facilidades que se le brindaron. Don José  trabaja  desde hace muchos años en la agricultura. El espera en un futuro brindarle tener una mayor estabilidad económica, y de poder seguir creciendo como persona y como productor.

About FUDECOSUR:
The Foundation for the Development of Southern Communities is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing credit and capacitating programs to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Southern Costa Rica. You can obtain more information on FUDECOSUR from the website: FUDECOSUR.org
texts.en:
Jose Leon G. F., 70, is single. He is applying for a loan to buy manure and fertilizer that he will use to grow coffee on a farm that he owns. He wants to do everything that he can to ensure the greatest yield possible and maximize his revenue from the crop. This isn't his first FUDECOSUR loan and he has been very happy with what he has been able to do with past loans. Don Jose has worked at farming for many years. He hopes that he'll be more economically secure in the future and be able to grow as a person and as a businessman.

About FUDECOSUR: The Foundation for the Development of Southern Communities is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing credit and capacitating programs to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Southern Costa Rica. You can obtain more information on FUDECOSUR from the website: FUDECOSUR.org

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Coffee farming.

loans.name: Lorena

texts.en:
Lorena A., 33, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. She is married to Joey A. and they are blessed with a child. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. She has been managing her own variety store for quite some time now.

Lorena has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her variety store.     

Now with your help, she would like to apply for a PHP 10,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital for her expanding business. She will use the loan funds to buy groceries to replenish the inventory of her variety store.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her child’s education.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy groceries to sell

loans.name: Jemarie

texts.en:
Jemarie P. is from the village of Brgy. Lactawan, Solano, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 28 years old. Jemarie is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Jemarie owns & operates a specialized retail store selling personal products in the local community. Jemarie has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Jemarie joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jemarie is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Jemarie from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Christiania

texts.en:
Christiania O. sells drinks at retail prices to her customers. She loves this drink business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. She hopes to be a major drink distributor in the future. She hopes for a loan of 100,000 Nigerian naira to purchase more drinks to sell. 

She is 54 years old and a widow with four children. Her children are doing well in their jobs and school. She is also happy because she is a grandmother. She hopes to see her business grow bigger and stronger. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell

loans.name: Florencia

texts.en:
Florencia M.’s greatest dream is to free herself from the spiral of poverty. In 1999, she decided to join Kiva partner, ASHI (which means “To Rise Up from Poverty”), in the Philippines. Since she joined ASHI, she has shown a good performance in her credit rating (the basis of loans) and is therefore able to borrow a larger amount of capital for her businesses.
As a busy entrepreneur, Florencia is engaged in multiple businesses – hog-fattening, retailing, frozen foods and sewing. These businesses allow her to save money as she and her husband get older. They want to enjoy their future retirement and be able to live with a happy family.
Florencia is now on her eleventh loan, and she has applied for the amount of 23,000 PHP to maintain her frozen food business, to buy additional piglets and feed, and support the inventory of her sewing business.
In the future, Florencia hopes to establish a stall in the nearby town market where she can take orders from her customers. Her dreams are to provide a better future for her family and sustain the profitability of her businesses. Through hard work and determination, Florencia is focused on improving her quality of life through her entrepreneurial initiatives and with support from ASHI and Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To maintain her frozen foods business, to buy additional piglets and feed, and support the inventory of her sewing business

loans.name: Renacer Group

texts.es:
Petronila Peña D. 49 años D. edad, es una D. las 7 integrantes D. la Alcancía Renacer que viene trabajando con Edaprospo Prosperidad desD. hace  5 meses, es casada y tiene 3 hijos  (2 mayores y  uno D. 14 años)
Se inicio con  el negocio D. venta D. ropa en forma ambulatoria y a pedidos desD. hace 10 años, y como no era suficiente el ingreso con el que contaba en ese entonces, decidió hacer otro  tipo D. negocio, dedicarse a la  preparación  y venta D.  tamales en su domicilio  desD. hace 4 y al ver que su ingreso iba mejorando decidió en invertir algo mas  en ella y fue entonces que por intermedio D. sus vecinas  que la  invitaron a participar en su alcancía obtuvo su primer préstamo el cual lo invirtió  en la compra  D.  insumos  para la preparación D. tamales (maíz, hoja D. plátano, pollo, y otros).
Su préstamo actual  lo invertirá en la compra D. una cocina industrial y claro está en mas ingredientes para la preparación D. sus tamales.
La meta que tiene en mente   y que viene persiguiendo,  ya desD. hace mucho tiempo es la compra  D. una moledora eléctrica, en lograr la apertura D.  una juglería  en una zona transcurrida por el público.
 Su  anhelo mayor es seguir  apoyando  a su  menor hijo en sus estudios tanto secundario  como Superior.
texts.en:
Petronila Peña, 49, is one of Renacer (To be Reborn) communal bank’s seven members who have been collaborating with Edaprospo Prosperidad for the last 5 months; she is married and has three children (two adults and one 14-year-old). She started out selling clothing door-to-door and via prior orders 10 years ago. Because this didn’t produce sufficient income she decided to open a second business: sale of home-maD. tamales. She has been in this second line of work for 4 years and, as her income increased, she decided to invest more into it. Thanks to an invitation to join the bank extended by some of her neighbors, she obtained her first loan which she used to buy ingredients for the tamales: corn, banana leaves, chicken, etc. Her current loan will be used to buy an industrial stove and, of course, more ingredients for tamale preparation. The goal she has in mind now and has had for a long time now and that she continues to strive for is to have an electric juicer and to open a juice bar in an area with lots of foot traffic. Her greatest wish is to continue to support her youngest son’s secondary and university education.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy an industrial stove and ingredients to make tamales.

loans.name: Buhumuriro Abarihamwe Group

texts.en:
A determined and very ambitious R. Kellen is the married mother of three children.

Kellen has operated a hardware business for three years in Rwempiri, Kazo town, selling cement, iron sheets, iron bars, wheelbarrows and more. At the end of every month she is able to fetch a profit of 300,0000 Ugandan shillings.

Kellen’s main drawback has been having a small amount of stock in her business that cannot match the consumption rate of her customers. She is seeking a loan that can help her to stock more goods that will satisfy her customers’ high demand and also transform her business into a wholesale operation.

Being very committed to her business with good customer care, Kellen hopes to increase her sales revenue. This will bring about a fundamental change in her business and enable her to achieve a self-sustaining life and cater for her family requirements.

loans.use: To restock her business and expand it into a wholesale operation

loans.name: Pet

texts.en:
Pet S., 28, is married and resides with her husband and a young child in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorean temples. 

She sells groceries for an income of about $1.60 USD per day. Her husband operates his truck to provide transportation services for workers at a garment factory, earning an income of $6.60 USD per day to help cover the family expenses.  S. is requesting a loan of $500 USD to purchase more groceries to stock the store.

In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to stock the store

loans.name: Minsito

texts.fr: Minsito T. est une femme de 59 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 05 enfants en charge elle est également tutrice de 02 autres enfants confiés par des proches. Elle est membre du Banc Villageois de SAMBA 15 ANS2 depuis le 17 juillet 2006. Elle a 2 activités qui consistent la vente de tissus teinté et la vente de glace et de jus de fruits naturel. L’objet de son crédit est de renforcer son activité et son objectif est d’assurer le payement de la scolarité de ses enfants et de participer aux dépenses quotidiennes de la famille.
texts.en:
Minsito T., 59, is married and raising five children; she is also the guardian of two other children, confided to her by their kinfolks. She has been a member of the Banc Villageois of SAMBA 15 ANS2 since July 17, 2006. She has two businesses, selling dyed cloth and also selling ice and natural fruit juice. The goal of her loan is to bolster her business and her intent is to make sure she can pay school fees for her children and participate in covering family expenses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: develop and promote her commercial activity

loans.name: Jesús Eduardo

texts.es: Jesús es de 30m años de edad, casado tiene un hijo varón, se dedica a la actividad de artesanía, elaboración de güipiles típicos, en la actividad tiene aproximadamente cinco años de experiencia, solicita su segundo préstamo para incrementar su capital de trabajo en compra de materiales, el anterior crédito lo pago sin problema de atraso, sus referencias personales indican que es una persona responsable y trabajador.
texts.en:
Jesús is 30 years old, he is married and has a son. He is a craftsman producing the traditional güipiles (woven ponchos), and he has been dedicating himself to this activity for about five years. He is requesting this second loan to increase his income and buy materials; he repaid the previous loan with no delay and he is know for being a responsible and hard-working man.

Translated from Spanish by Emanuela Villa, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy materials

loans.name: Teko Robert

texts.fr: gadzi teko est un homme  très dynamique, il est marié et père de 2 enfants , il y a 5 ans de cela il s'est lancé dans le commerce de détail de vidéo cassettes, CD audio, baffle et autres. il a ouvert une petite cabine dans laquelle il fait son commerce. la demande actuelle de ses clients est élevée, pour les satisfaire il doit se réapprovisionner raison pour laquelle il demande son premier prêt de WAGES pour l'achat de 6 baffles, 4 amplificateurs et des CD
texts.en:
Gadzi Teko is a very energetic man, married with two children. Five years ago he began selling videocassettes, audio CDs, speaker baffles and other products. He opened a small store for his business. Customer demand has increased, and to satisfy it he needs to build inventory. For that reason, he is asking for his first loan from WAGES to buy 6 baffles, 4 speakers and CDs.

Translated from French by Michael Briggs, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy baffles, speakers and audio CDs

loans.name: Francisca

texts.en: Francisca E. is from the village of Brgy. Nagcuartelan, Aritao, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 54 years old. Francisca is married and has four adult children. To make a living, Francisca owns and operates a business venture in the food sector. The main source of income for the business comes from making and selling snacks in the local community. Francisca has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 5,100 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2007, Francisca joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Francisca has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Francisca is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This will be the sixth loan taken out by Francisca from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand it. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand her product offering

loans.name: Bagdat

texts.ru:
Bagdat G. 45 let. On jenat i imeyet 2 detey  sin kotoromu 16 let i doch kotoroy 10 let. Eqo sin uchitsya v shkole  i zanimayestya sportom i dochka toje uchitsya v shkole v to je vremya zanimayestya tancami.  On i eqo semya jivut v Fuzuli regione. 

Etomu biznesu on nauchilsya u svoeqo starsheqo brata i potom reshil sebe otrik maqazin . On uje 7 let rabotayet v etom maqazine . Seychas on nujdayetsya 2000 AZN chtobi kupit produkti dlya pereprodaji . V budushem on xotelbi uvelichit pomesheniye svoeqo maqazina.
texts.en:
Bagdat G. is 45 years old. He is married and has two children, a 16-year-old son and 10-year-old daughter. His son studies in school and engages in sports, and his daughter also is in school and studies dance in her free time. He and his family live in the Fuzuli region. He started his business with his older brother and then decided to open his own shop. On has been working in this store for seven years. Now he needs a loan in order to purchase products for resale. In the future, he wishes to expand the offerings in his store.

Translated from Russian by JD Bergeron, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase food products

loans.name: Jenny

texts.en:
Jenny C., 29, a resident of Commonwealth, Quezon City, Philippines, is married to Cubreguito C., a vendor; she is the mother of two children, one of whom is in elementary school, while the youngest is toddling around at home. By the grace of God, Jenny has managed to support her older child's schooling. At this time, she is working hard to be able to send her children all the way through college, a dream of most Filipino parents like Jenny who herself has been a college undergraduate and believes that a college diploma is the best legacy parents can give to their children.

Jenny operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go for to buy one sachet of shampoo, a Php5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. Her store is located adjacent to her house, and her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of Php300 in sales every day.

To help her continue operation of her business, Jenny is requesting a Php21,000 loan to buy more quantities of products including groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.

Jenny dreams of being able to give her all her children a good and high quality education through all of her hard work on her business. She dreams of becoming a successful businesswoman someday, and faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners who gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy more quantities of products to expand her inventory

loans.name: 050303-Hai Long-Hoang Phong Group

texts.en:
Xuyen T. T. (8) is a 51-year-old woman living in the town of Hoang Hoa.  Xuyen is the group leader of a 4-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  WhiL. each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsibL. for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.  The official name of this borrowing group is 050303-Hai long-Hoang Phong (050303-Hai long-Hoang phong).

Xuyen is married and has 4 adult children.  To make a living, Xuyen operates a family member's business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock.  WhiL. not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from raising chickens for saL..  Xuyen has been engaged in this business for over 30 years and earns approximately 1,000,000 VND a month from these activities.

In 2005, Xuyen joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Xuyen has successfully repaid a previous loan of 1,626,900 VND from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  This previous loan was used to purchase breeding livestock.  She is now requesting a new loan of 5,000,000 VND which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future.  The will be the 5th loan taken out by the borrower from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  Xuyen plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.


About the Other Borrowers in the Group:


1.  L. T. Vinh (15) is a 50-year-old femaL. who is requesting a 5000000 VND loan to support her fishing business.


2.  L. T. Anh (18) is a 31-year-old femaL. who is requesting a 5000000 VND loan to support her fishing business.


3.  L. T. Doan (16) is a 37-year-old femaL. who is requesting a 5000000 VND loan to support her  fishing business.


About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

The mission of Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainabL. financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province.


*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese whiL. providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.


Xuyen T. T. (8) là 51 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Hoang Hoa.  Xuyen là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 4 các thành viên.  Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ..  Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 050303-Hai long-Hoang phong (050303-Hai long-Hoang phong).


Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ chăn nuôi gà để bán.  Xuyen thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 30 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, Xuyen kiếm được khoảng 1,000,000 VND.  Vào 2005, Xuyen đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải T.ện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  Xuyen đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 1,626,900 VND từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua con giống.  Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 5,000,000 VND.


Khoản vay sẽ là 5th khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.


Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:


1.  L. T. Vinh (15) là 50 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5000000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh hải sản.


2.  L. T. Anh (18) là 31 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5000000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh hải sản.


3.  L. T. Doan (16) là 37 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5000000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh hải sản.


Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ Hỗ trợ Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa.


*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.

loans.use: to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future

loans.name: Pioneros De Huaquillay Group

texts.es:
Digna es socia D. la alcancía comunal “PIONEROS D. HUAQUILLAY”, está conformado por 7 miembros emprendedores quienes viven en la zona D. Huaquillay, distrito D. Comas, departamento D. Lima, trabajan con EDAPROSPO-prosperidad desD. hace 8 años.

Digna tiene 50 años, es separada, tiene 3 hijos D. los cuales 2 son menores D. edad. Delia desD. hace 20 años se dedica a la venta D. micas en las afueras D. un banco, se inicio en este negocio porque en un inicio empezó vendiendo pimienta y comino como ambulante en un mercado, pero a raíz D. que aperturaron un banco cerca a su domicilio y habían muchas personas circulando decidió cambiar D. giro D. negocio. Con el esfuerzo D. su trabajo ha logrado solo pueD. cubrir loa gastos D. alimentos, servicios y educación D. sus 2 menores hijos. El gran sueño D. Digna es poner un negocio en su propia casa.

Con el préstamo otorgado Digna lo utilizara en la compra D. mercadería. Agradecen el apoyo brindado e iniciativa para su constitución como Alcancía Comunal y prometen cumplir con los pagos establecidos en las fechas pactadas.
texts.en:
The “PIONEROS D. HUAQUILLAY” communal bank is maD. up of seven entrepreneurial members who live in the Huaquillay zone of the Comas district and Lima department.  They’ve been working with EDAPROSPO-Prosperidad for eight years.

Digna, who is a part of the group, is 50 years old.  She is separated and has three children, two of who are minors.  Delia has been selling plastic items outsiD. a bank.  She started doing this because at one time she had been selling pepper and cumin on foot in a marketplace, but they opened a bank near her home and there were many people around there, so she decided to change lines of business.

With the effort that she puts into her work, she is able to cover her family’s food expenses, services, and cost of her children’s education.  Her greatest dream is to run a business out of her home.

Digna will use the money from this loan to buy merchandise.  They appreciate the support and the start of their communal bank and they promise to make their payments on the agreed upon dates.

loans.use: Inventory

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en: Josephine is a 32-year-old married lady. She makes and sells curios and woven baskets to earn a living. She also gets financial support from her husband who is employed. She has been in her business for four years. She is thankful to Faulu Kenya for supporting her financially – this has led to growth in her business. So far, she has managed to employ three people. She hopes to expand her business to other towns in the future. She has requested a loan of 50,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) to buy raw materials such as bamboo and metal for making her products.

loans.use: To buy raw materials such as bamboo and metals

loans.name: Jantetelco Group

texts.es: Este grupo solidario se llama Jantetelco, se encuentra localizado en la comunidad de Jantetelco, en el estado de Morelos, México, este grupo está conformado por 6 integrantes mujeres que se conocen y son vecinas ellas son la señora Misael B. N. y va a comprar con su préstamo ropa por mayoreo para vender y un poco de zapatos vende por catalogo, la señora Norma C. R. va a comprar perfumes, labiales etc., la señora Carlota E. J. va a comprar todo tipo de dulces para vender, frijol, zapatos vende por catalogo, la señora Eva Rodríguez A. va a comprar productos de belleza, ropa, etc., la señora Buenaventura S. Lena va a comprar forraje alimento para sus vacas, la señora Minerva R. E. va a comprar zapatos en catalogo para vender. La señora Eva Rodríguez A. es integrante del grupo Jantetelco, ella tiene 45 años de edad, estudio en la normal para maestra de primaria terminando de estudiar la secundaria entro en la normal de Puebla estudio 4 años para maestra, ella tiene 3 hijos Javier tiene 22 años de edad apenas se recibió, Joselin tiene 21 años de edad es soltera estudia en la universidad sicología y un curso de ingles, Iván tiene 10 años de edad está estudiando la primaria, la señora Eva solicito su préstamo para invertir en el negocio de cosméticos y artículos para el hogar, su negocio es ambulante sale a ofrecer sus productos, también la van a ver a su casa cuando quieren algo para regalo, sus clientes son sus vecinos, conocidos y familiares, los productos que les ofrece a sus clientes son cosméticos, perfumes, labiales, desodorantes, cremas, barniz, rímel y artículos para el hogar, bajillas, baterías, cucharas, sobrecamas, sabanas. Ella inicio con el negocio hace 20 años desde que estaba soltera, su mama también se dedicaba a este negocio y ella le enseño y le animo, ella estudiaba entre semana y los sábados y domingos salía a ofrecer los productos con sus conocidos, adquirió su negocio con las ganancias fue comprando mercancía y ahorita para crecer más con los apoyos de los créditos y está muy contenta con este préstamo que le proporciona por que va a surtirse de mercancía. Su negocio es importante porque gana dinero y se distrae hay de todo se ríe, se enoja y lo que más le gusta es convivir con las personas, le proporciona gran satisfacción tener un dinero de mas, su negocio es popular sus clientes la recomiendan a más personas, los desafíos que enfrenta son los costos no siempre es el mismo precio, suben los precios, las ganancias las vuelve a reinvertir y en alguna cosa que le gusta, ella está planeando ampliarlo meter otras cosas que no vende ,meter mercancía diferentes como calzado y lo pieza lograr echándole mas ganas vendiendo mas. Este negocio le ha ayudado en lo económico le ha podido dar estudios a sus hijos, arreglar su casa y sus sueños son que siga creciendo el negocio y su hijo el chico que siga estudiando para que tenga una carrera, ahorita como quiera ya están saliendo sus hijos más grandes.  Jantetelco es un lugar bonito, es fresco, tranquilo, hay mucha vegetación, hacen dulces cristalizados como el camote, el jamoncillo, chilacayote. Los integrantes del grupo quieren decir a Kiva y a Fundación Realidad ”gracias por su apoyo ya que su ayuda a que sigan creciendo los negocio”.
texts.en:
The name of this group is Jantetelco and it is located in the community of Jantetelco in the state of Morelos, Mexico. This group is made up of 6 women who are all known to each other as neighbors. 

Misael B. N. is a member and she will use her loan to purchase clothing in wholesale and shoes from a catalogue. 

Norma C. R. will purchase perfumes and makeup. 

Carlota E. J. will purchase all kinds of candies for resale and she will also purchase beans and shoes. 

Eva R. A. will purchase beauty products, clothing etc. 

Mrs. Buenaventura S. Lena will purchase feed for her cattle. 

Minerva R. E. will purchase shoes from a catalogue to resell. 

Eva R. A. is a member of the Jantetelco group and she is 45 years old. She started out from very young to train to be a teacher. When she finished high school she studied 4 years in teacher's college. She has 3 children: Javier is 22 years old and has graduated high school; Joselin is 21 years old, she is single and she is studying Sociology and English in university; and Ivan is 10 years old and he is in primary school. Eva requested a loan to invest in her cosmetics business and to purchase articles for the home. She travels door to door selling her products but clients also come to her home when they need to purchase a gift. Her clients are her neighbors, her acquaintances, and her family. She sells products such as cosmetics, perfumes, lipsticks, deodorants, skin creams, nail polish, Rimel brand products and household articles such as dinnerware, batteries, spoons and bedding.  She started her business 20 years ago when she was still single. Her mother was also in this business and she showed her and grew interested. She went to school during the week and on Saturdays and Sunday she would go out to sell her products to her clients. She set up her business with her own savings. She started to buy merchandise and today she is able to expand her business even more with the help of these loans. She is very happy to receive this loan because she will be able to add variety to her inventory. Her business is important because she is able to earn money and it is a distraction for her. She laughs, she cries, but the best part about the work is being in contact with other. She gets great satisfaction for have money. Her business is popular and clients recommend others to come. The challenge she faces is having to deal with fluctuating prices.  Sometimes prices go up. She reinvests her earnings in something she enjoys. She is planning to expand the variety in what she sells. She wants to start selling shoes and to reach her goal she will sell more with even greater fervor. This business has helped her financially and she has been able to send her children to school and bring about some renovations to their home.  Her dream is to see her business expand even more. She also dreams of seeing her youngest son continue going to school to have a career.  In whichever way possible her two eldest kids are almost ready to be independent. 

Jantetelco is a beautiful place, cool and tranquil with a great deal of vegetation. They make candies from yams, milk, and berries. The members of this group wish to covey a note of thanks to Kiva and Fundacion Realidad for the support provided to them for the development of their business.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for resale.

loans.name: Karina

texts.es: Karina, de 32 años, es una mujer muy sincera y trabajadora, vive en su casa propia junto a sus 2 queridas hijas Neyla de 8 y Sofía de 4 años, quienes son el principal motivo de todos sus esfuerzos. En el poblado de Kimbiri, Karina tiene un pequeño puesto donde vende combustible, con el cual abastece a todos los carros que pasan por la carretera, su puesto es muy concurrido y por lo general acaba con todo el combustible que vende, tiene 8 años en este negocio, el cual le ha dado las ganancias suficientes para alimentar a sus hijas y pagar sus estudios, pero siente que el dinero que gana no será suficiente para correr con los gastos de los estudios secundarios de sus queridas hijas, es por eso que desea poner una tienda con la cual pueda incrementar sus ingresos económicos. A ella le gusta conversar con sus clientes, disfruta mucho haciéndolo, pero le es muy difícil permanecer todo el día en su negocio, ya que el olor del combustible es muy fuerte y termina mareándola, aun así no decae en su afán de salir adelante y esta dispuesta a trabajar mucho para lograrlo. Es el segundo crédito con MFP, sabe que tiene que pagar todas sus cuotas a tiempo y esta dispuesta a hacerlo, ya que no quiere causarle problemas a las socias de su banco comunal, en el cual es muy responsable. Con los dos mil nuevos soles solicitados, comprará más combustible, para generarse mejores ingresos económicos.
texts.en:
Karina is 32 years old.  She is a very sincere and hard-working woman who lives in her own home with her 2 beloved daughters, Neyla who is 8 and Sofia who is 4.  Her children are her main reason for making all her efforts.  In the town of Kimbiri, Karina has a small stall where she sells fuel to passing cars.  Her stall is very busy and generally she manages to sell all her fuel.  She has been in this business for 8 years and it has provided her with enough profits to feed her daughters and pay for their studies.  However, she feels that the money she makes will not be enough to cover the expenses of her daughters' secondary education.  For this reason, she would like to set up a store with which she can increase her income.  She really enjoys chatting to her customers.  She enjoys it a lot but it is very difficult for her to stay in her business all day since the smell of fuel is very strong and it ends up making her feel sick.  Even so, she doesn't flag in her desire to get ahead and she is ready to work hard to do so.

This is her second loan from MFP.  She knows that she has to make all her repayments on time and she is ready to do so since she doesn't want to cause problems for the other members of her community bank, being a responsible woman.  She will use the 2,000 nuevos soles she is requesting to buy more fuel to make better profits.

loans.use: To buy more fuel to make more profit

loans.name: Harriet

texts.en: Harriet is a 30-year-old inspired woman, married to an accountant. They have three children and live in a rented house in Fort Portal, Uganda. Harriet has had a retail shop for five years now and this business has helped her to pay school fees for her children. Harriet needs money to buy more sugar, soap and rice to sell.

loans.use: To buy sugar, soap and rice to sell

loans.name: Esther

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal “LIDERANDO LAS PALMERAS”; El banco está ubicado en el distrito de Cusco, perteneciente a la provincia de Cusco y departamento de Cusco.

La socia es la Sra. Esther; ella tiene 37 años de edad y es casada y tiene 2 hijos; La socia alterna sus actividades diarias con el negocio de venta de cosméticos en forma independiente, ella lleva a diferentes instituciones o público en general, ella quiere tener una tienda donde pueda vender los cosméticos. La socia solicita el préstamo para comprar cosméticos al por mayor como lápiz labiales, perfumes y esmaltes para uñas.

La socia agradece a quienes forman parte de este sueño mediante este medio y se compromete a cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
Esther, 37, is a member of the “LIDERANDO LAS PALMERAS” (Leading the Palm Trees) communal bank which is located in Cusco district that is part of Cusco province, Cusco department.

She’s married and has two children.  She combines her daily chores with an independent cosmetics sales business.  She sells to various institutions and to the general public.  She’d like to have a store where she can sell her cosmetics.  She’s asking for a loan to buy cosmetics like lipsticks, perfumes and nail polish at wholesale.

He thanks all those who share her dream and pledges to repay in a timely fashion.

loans.use: To buy cosmetics like lip sticks, perfumes and nail polish at wholesale.

loans.name: Rabie

texts.en:
Rabie is the father of seven children: three daughters and four sons, who are all students. Rabie inherited his shop from his father and has been running it for five years now. He started work with his father at a young age and gained good experience dealing with customers.

Rabie came to FATEN and asked for a loan to improve the shop and add more shelves. Rabie appears in the picture here in front of his store.

loans.use: To improve a car accessories store

loans.name: Enhamgalan

texts.en:
Enhamgalan G.  is 40 years old and lives with his wife and son in Hentii province of Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger,  a traditional Mongolian  tent home. His oldest son attends a local high school and his wife helps him with the business. 

Enhamgalan operates a wood-products trading business in his town. He makes a variety of wooden products such as chairs, tables and doors for gers, depending on his customers' orders. He started his wood product-making business in 2001 after operating a iron/metal production business since 1991. In addition, he operates a construction business to supplement his earnings, building homes to customers' orders. 

Enhamgalan has built a stable base of operations for both businesses and his business earnings have increased greatly. With his earnings, he was able to purchase his own plot of land.  In the future, he plans to build his own house for his family. He is requesting a 1,300,000 MNT loan to purchase wood for his wood-products business.

loans.use: To purchase wood

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn T. is from the town of Banga. She is 39 years old. Jocelyn is married and has 4 children, aged 6, 13, 15 and 18. To make a living, Jocelyn owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice and corn for sale. Jocelyn has been engaged in farming for 18 years.

Jocelyn joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jocelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Jocelyn is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizer  and other farm supplies. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay for her children's tuition fees.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer  and other farm supplies

loans.name: Olivia

texts.en: Olivia is a married woman who lives in Madredijos, Cebu. She earns her living by selling fish and eggs and with a general store. Her husband, Tito B., age 52, works as a fisherman and also helps with his wife's business activities. They have five children who are 18 to 32 years old. Olivia joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2000 because she wanted something better for her family. With the help of her past 16 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, and by the sweat of her brow, Olivia has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty. Her previous loan of 29,500 Philippine pesos (PHP) helped her earn a monthly profit of 10,000 PHP, improving her family's standard of living. This time, for her 17th loan, she is borrowing 29,500 PHP, which she intends to use to purchase additional stock for her business. She is saving up for house repairs. Olivia is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To fund the operations of her business

loans.name: Edgar

texts.en:
Edgar Y. is from the town of Banga. He is 38 years old. Edgar is married and has 2 children aged 8 and 4. To make a living, Edgar owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting & harvesting corn and rice for sale. Edgar works very hard  to sustain his family and pay for his children's education.

Edgar joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Edgar has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Edgar is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to purchase seeds, fertilizer and other farm supplies. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay his children's school fees.

loans.use: to purchase seeds, fertilizer and other farm supplies

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph is 29 years old and is married. Joseph makes a living by selling a variety of goods such as sugar, rice, cooking oil and more. Joseph's business is open from 6am until 6pm every day and he has three years of experience.

Joseph has requested a loan from Kiva in order to purchase additional cooking and sugar to sell. With this loan, Joseph will hopefully earn more profits, which in turn will allow him to keep reinvesting in his business and saving for a better future.

loans.use: To purchase additional oil sugar and rice to sell.

loans.name: Hem

texts.en:
Mrs. Hem P., age 40, has been a primary school teacher since 1990 and earns an income about $1.60 per day. Her husband, Much Samen, age 43, is a construction worker, and he can make a profit of approximately $1.60 per day. They have two children, but their children don’t have jobs yet. 

Mrs. Hem P. will be using her loan to add to her personal savings to buy a plot of farmland near her house, which is a good location for farming. She will rent out this land to farmers for a fee. She says that this loan will provide her with an additional new fixed asset. 

Mrs. Hem P. and her husband were taken in the photo.

loans.use: to buy a plot of farmland to rent to a farmer

loans.name: Marly

texts.en:
Marly C. is from the village of Sinonoc, Sinacaban, Misamis Occidental. She is 35 years old. Marly is married and has 1 school-aged child. To make a living, Marly owns & operates a retail store, selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap & toothpaste in the local community.  She has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2011, Marly joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marly is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP to purchase rice and corn grits to sell. This will be her first loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve/expand her business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has seven branches covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: purchase rice and corn grits to sell

loans.name: Mary Ann

texts.en:
Mary Ann D. is from the village of Kalagutay, Ninoy Aquino, Kalilangan, Bukidnon. She is 29 years old, married, and has three children. To make a living, Mary Ann owns and operates a motorela business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing motorela or habal-habal services to local community members. Mary Ann has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 14,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Mary Ann joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mary Ann has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from HSPFI, which was used to to purchase tools needed to provide service. Mary Ann is requesting a new loan of 23,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase tools and utilities needed for the maintenance of her motorela. This loan will be Mary Ann's seventh loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase tools and utilities needed for the maintenance of a motorela

loans.name: Gregoria Lurdes

texts.es: La señora Gregoria tiene como principal actividad económica  el comercio en una tienda de barrio donde vende refrescos, abarrotes, conservas y golosinas, esta ubicada en la zona de pasankeri, su esposo es transportista propietario. Viven en la zona de Sopocachi en su domicilio propio, trabajan ambos todos los días para el bienestar de sus hijos. La Sra. Gregoria es cliente de emprender por mas de tres años es una cliente puntual y muy responsable, antes pertenecía al grupo solidario los pinos. El crédito que solicita ahora es para la compra de fruta, porque ella decidió comercializar también mandarinas, naranjas y manzanas porque en esta época del año es una actividad que da buenos ingresos.
texts.en:
Gregoria's main source of income is her neighborhood store, located in the Pasankeri area, where she sales soft drinks, groceries, canned food, and candies.  Her husband works in transportation.  They live in their home, which they own, in the Sopocachi area.  They both work everyday to take care of their kids.  

As a client of Emprender for the last three years, Gregoria has been punctual and dependable.  She used to be a member of the communal bank Los Pinos.  

The loan she is requesting will be used to buy fruit such as oranges, apples, which she has decided to sale during this time of year as earnings will be good.

loans.use: buy fruit

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita is now 51 years old and married with six adult-aged children. Teresita is a farmer working in the Philippines who earns PHP 7,000 per month. 

Teresita is asking for a loan of PHP 8,000 to purchase additional crops to raise and to pay for services to increase her crop yields. Teresita has been growing root crops for almost 30 years.

In the future, Teresita hopes to produce more root crops and earn a higher income in order to support the needs of her family. She believes that she can improve their living conditions through patience and hard work.

loans.use: to purchase additional crops to raise and to pay for services to increase crop yields

loans.name: Regina

texts.en:
Regina is a 51-year-old married lady with two children. She sells charcoal in the Majengo Mapya area in Malindi and has been in this business for the past five years now. She earns a monthly income of about 5,000 Kenyan Shillings (KES) from her business and usually uses the money to assist her husband in taking care of their family and educating their children.

Regina has asked for a loan of KES 35,000 from KADET LTD. This is her fourth loan from the company. She intends to use her loan to purchase additional sacks of charcoal and put up a strong wooden structure for her business, with a view to being able to serve her ever growing numbers of customers in the area. No one else has the same kind of business in the region. She plans to use the anticipated profits to add to her stock.

In the future she hopes to open a water selling point in the town.

loans.use: to purchase additional sacks of charcoal and put up a wooden structure.

loans.name: Ryssalatou

texts.fr: Revendeuse de légumes et boites de conserves, Rysselatou est mère de 02 enfants. Son conjoint est policier. Elle s’approvisionne à Baguida et revend au même lieu. Ce prêt lui servira à acheter des marchandises.
texts.en: A retailer of vegetables and canned food, Rysselatou is the mother of two children. Her husband is a police officer. She buys and resells in Baguida. This loan will be used to buy goods.

loans.use: to buy staple food items
