She plans to use this loan to a buy more bunches of bananas. She buys these bananas from villages of Masaka in south central Uganda. Mary uses public transport to and from Masaka, where she goes for shopping once a week. She has been in this business for 10 years and she also sells furniture to get additional income. 

She receives an average of 30 people and sells both on a retail and wholesale basis. Her customers are the people in the market and nearby communities. She works seven days a week. She depends on this job for a living. Her business challenges are transportation and seasonality.   

She aspires to see her business grow big and to build her own house. Mary decided to work with MCDT because she wanted additional capital. 

She resides in and owns a two-roomed house and the family has no access to electricity or piped water. Her monthly expenses include school fees, food and market dues.

loans.use: To buy more bunches of bananas

loans.name: Nelia

texts.en: To make a living, Nelia P. runs a general store selling both food and daily use products in her community. She is 55 years old, married and has five grown-up children. She is from the village of Bagong Sikat, Alicia, Isabela. Nelia has been in her business for over two years and earns approximately 4,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. In 2009, Nelia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Nelia is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her third loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve and expand her business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Efua

texts.en:
Efua A. is married and has four children. Her husband is a driver and Efua uses her income to support her husband in providing the needs of the children such as feeding and clothing. She has no educational background.

Efua buys fresh fish and smokes it for sale at Takoradi. She will use the loan to purchase more fish to smoke for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, she plans to save to educate her children.

loans.use: To purchase more fish to smoke for sale

loans.name: Maame

texts.en:
Maame K. is married and has a child. She has received senior high education. Her husband is a miner.

Maame operates a provision shop at Takoradi and uses the income she generates from her sales to educate her child with the help of her husband. She will use the loan to purchase more provisions to sell.

With the new profits from her expanded business, Maame plans to save towards her child’s education.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions to sell

loans.name: Manzura Kazybekova's Group

texts.en:
Sometimes life is not as would be normally expected. Even a highly educated person must have a good sense of luck. In Kyrgyzstan, especially in villages, people have learned to work hard. Most often this work is manual labor. But as is known, any kind of labor is good.

Manzura K. is the leader of this group. She is 31, married and has two young children who go to the nursery school “Ak Kaiyn.” Her husband is a crane operator. Manzura is a first category specialist in sports and works in the House of Culture. In past years she did house repairs. Manzura also breeds livestock to sell. With money received from the loan she wants to purchase two sheep for breeding. In the near future the family wants to buy a Volkswagen.

Nargiza D. is the treasurer of this group. She is 25, married and is temporarily bringing up her daughter by herself because her husband is working in Russia. By leaving the child in a kindergarten, she has had more time to work at her business of breeding cattle. She has been doing so successfully for four years, yet the family can’t afford major purchases. She needs a loan in order to buy two goats for breeding. Nargiza still cherishes the hope of buying a new house with modern conveniences.

Almazbek S., 25, is a bachelor. He raises money by breeding cattle. Presently he has one cow and eleven goats. He would like a loan to buy two more goats for breeding. Almazbek is planning to marry in the near future.

Eliza D., 22, is married to a private builder. The couple has two small daughters. This young wife raises money by breeding cattle. As a result of hard work, she has three head of livestock. Eliza needs a loan to buy two goats for breeding. She wishes to obtain a car for herself.

About Mol Bulak Finance:

This loan is being presented by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious, socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of its “3-Ps” concept: People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow larger) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year.

To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team—Supporters of Kyrgyzstan—at: http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: to purchase sheep

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This borrower is 43 years old and is married with five children. She graduated from primary school.

She will use this loan to improve her business by purchasing a table and chair and an embroidery machine. She has a good reputation and is a worthy and trusted borrower.

She is supporting her husband with her good business in order to raise their standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase an embroidery machine and a table and chair

loans.name: Julia

texts.en:
Julia C. is a 45-year old married woman who supports her family by running a vegetable plantation. She lives in Lower Ilian within Barangay Dumarao, a part of Roxas municipality, Palawan province on the island region of MIMAROPA. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2008 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard on her vegetable plantation, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of 5,000 PHP.

Julia is now borrowing 12,500 PHP so that she can use it as additional working capital. This will be her fifth loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of 11,000 PHP, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Julia aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the Dungganon way.

About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through its alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a dollar a day to achieving realities beyond their dreams. They are on a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon—a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: For additional working capital for her farm

loans.name: Luz

texts.es: Luz, D. 41 años, vive al lado D. su esposo Rubén D. 48 años y D. sus 3 jóvenes hijos, que son mayores D. edad, y juntos se esfuerzan cada día para salir adelante. DesD. hace 2 años, esta emprendedora mujer instaló en su casa un negocio D. alquiler D. cabinas D. Internet. Empieza su labor desD. las 9 D. la mañana y se prolonga hasta las 10 D. la noche; y esta muy satisfecha pues sus hijos la apoyan en la atención cuando ella debe salir. Aunque el negocio es tranquilo, manifiesta que es algo sacrificado, pues muchas veces sus clientes le piden que deje abierto el local hasta tarD., pero por las buenas ganancias que obtiene, trata D. sacrificarse y continuar trabajando para ayudar a su esposo en los constantes gastos del hogar. Con el pasar del tiempo ha captado buenos clientes que la visitan seguido, además ha logrado implementar mejor sus cabinas D. Internet. Como siempre planea el futuro ampliar el negocio, asimismo quiere instalar un local D. alquiler D. videojuegos. Es el décimo crédito que tiene con MFP y promete pagar sus cuotas puntualmente, pues no quiere quedar mal con las personas que hicieron posible este préstamo que le permitirá continuar trabajando en busca del progreso. Luz  tiene planeado invertir el crédito solicitado en la compra D. 2 videojuegos para empezar con el futuro negocio con el que asegura mejorará sus ganancias.
texts.en:
Luz is 41 years old.  She lives with her 48 year-old husband Rubén and her 3 grown-up children.  They work hard every day to get ahead in life.  Two years ago this entrepreneurial woman set up an Internet café in her house.  She starts working at 9 o'clock in the morning and works until 10 o'clock at night.  She is very happy because her children help to mind the business when she has to go out.  Although the business is relaxed, she says that she has to make sacrifices because very often her customers ask her to stay open until late.  However, because she makes a good income, she tries to make these sacrifices and continues to work in order to help her husband with the constant household expenses.  Over time, she has attracted good customers who keep coming back.  She has also managed to set up her Internet stations better.  In the future, she is planning to expand her business and she also wants to set up a video game rental place.

This will be the tenth loan which Luz has had from MFP and she pledges to make her repayments in a timely manner because she does not want to give a bad impression to the people who, through funding her loan, will allow her to continue working in search of progress.  Luz plans to invest the loan in the purchase of 2 video games in order to begin her future business which she says she will improve her income.

loans.use: To purchase two video games in order to set up her business

loans.name: Veronica Segundina

texts.es:
Verónica es socia del Banco Comunal “Santiago Apóstol” ubicado en el distrito de Paucarcolla, provincia de Puno, departamento de Puno, tiene 40 años de edad, de estado civil conviviente, tiene cuatro hijos y con grado de instrucción de educación primaria  incompleta.
Verónica viene trabajando con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos desde hace cinco años, el primer préstamo solicitado fue de S/ 300.00 nuevos soles, el cual pudo usar en su negocio de venta de pescado específicamente Karachi y pejerrey.
Ahora solicitara un nuevo préstamo de S/ 1000.00 nuevos soles, préstamo que invertirá en su negocio.
Su sueño es seguir adelante con su negocio. Lo que le gusta del Banco Comunal  es la solidaridad.
texts.en:
Verónica is a member of the Communal Bank “Santiago Apóstol”, which is located in the District of Paucarcolla, Province and Department of Puno. She is 40 years old, in a common law marriage, and has four children. Verónica did not finish her elementary school education.

She has been working with Manuela Ramos for five years. The first loan she requested was for 300 PEN, which she used for her business of selling fish, especially “carache” and “pejerrey”.

Now she is requesting a new loan in the amount of 1000 PEN to invest in her business. Verónica’s dream is to continue forward with her business. What she enjoys most about her Communal Bank is the solidarity.

loans.use: Operating capital for selling fish

loans.name: Thomas

texts.en: Thomas is a thirty-eight-year-old married man who is blessed with five children. He lives in his own house in Fort Portal, Uganda. He aspires to have an educated family and become a model household in the village. He sells firewood for a living. He has been in the field for three years and it has enabled him to pay school fees for his children. His passion is to have a store that supplies a bigger area. Thomas needs the loan to purchase firewood to sell.

loans.use: To buy firewood to sell

loans.name: Juliana Anamoa

texts.en: Juliana Anamoa M. sells soft drinks at Akotokyir, near Abura. She is married and has been in this business for five years now. She assists her husband in taking care of the home. Her loan will be used to buy more soft drinks to meet the demands of her customers. She hopes to reinvest the additional income as a result of the loan.

loans.use: To buy soft drinks to sell

loans.name: Abena

texts.en:
Abena A. sells smoked fish, fried fish and fante kenkey, a food staple made from fermented maize dough wrapped in leaves.  Abena has been educated through junior high school.  She is married and has four children. Her husband taps palm trees for palm wine to make a living, and Abena assists her husband in paying school fees and utility bills. 

She sells her goods in Takoradi and demand is high.  Abena is looking to expand her business to increase her profit. She wishes to increase production and sales, so she is asking for a loan to buy fish to fry and maize to prepare fante kenkey for sale.

By Abena's left hand, a row of fante kenkey is visible.  On her right side, there is a wooden tray with fried fish arranged for sale.

loans.use: To buy fish and maize.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 30-year-old married man from Lebanon living with his wife and one child. He cooperates earning the family income with his wife who owns a home maid office.  After having13 years of experience in the clothing field, he decided in 2009 to open a clothing store. He purchases his products from a local clothing center. 

Today, he is requesting to borrow $1200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase supplementary products to increase his sales and therefore his family’s financial level.

loans.use: To purchase supplementary products

loans.name: Nestor

texts.en:
Nestor R. is from the village of Samonte. He is 52 years old. Nestor is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Nestor owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Nestor has been engaged in his business for over 32 years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Nestor joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nestor is requesting a new loan of 25000 PHP which will be used to pay for services to increase crop yield. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Nestor from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees for his children. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to pay for services to increase crop yield

loans.name: Chhiev's Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan consists of seventeen members. They are living in Prey Prasat village in Kandal province. 

Mrs. Chhiev K., married woman, was born in 1972, and she is a village bank president. She was selected to be the village bank president by the other members. She is a congee (rice porridge) seller in the local village. Since her business is doing well, she wants to expand it. Thus, she would like to ask for a loan to purchase more congee supplies to enlarge her business activities. Her husband, Mr. Phang Sandap, is a construction worker. With their occupations, they are able to earn a small income to support their family living. 

This couple is working to support their four children: three are attending a local school and the youngest is 3 years old.

loans.use: To purchase more congee  ( rice porridge) supplies to enlarge her business activities.

loans.name: Jenny

texts.en:
Jenny and her husband are both farmers. They cultivate their land to plant and harvest rice crops. They are currently preparing their land for planting. Jenny, a member of CEVI, applied for a loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm supplies. This loan will truly help Jenny have a good harvest.

Jenny is 41 years old, married and has 2 children aged 10 and 8. She works hard to sustain her children's education. She dreams for them to have bright futures.

loans.use: To purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm supplies.

loans.name: Pilar

texts.en:
Mrs. Pilar M., age 67, is a widow living in Dulapo, Oroquieta, Misamis Occidental. She has six children. After she learned about Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative, she got interested and joined the co-op in October 2002.

She has started a business running a sari-sari (variety) store. She is applying for a PHP 14,900 loan in order to buy additional goods. It is entirely thanks to the co-operative financing her endeavors that she is able to implement this project. She hopes her business will be more profitable and that she will see all her children become successful someday.

loans.use: to buy additional goods to offer for sale in her store

loans.name: Mwanabarawa

texts.en:
Mwanabarawa is a married woman with 5 school-going children. They own a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family. For the past three years, she has operated a retail business selling household goods to her neighbors and passersby. She operates from Monday to Friday, selling consumable goods on a daily basis. 

Mwanabarawa faces a major challenge of theft because of insecurity in her place of operation. She dreams of establishing a wholesale shop in the future. With the 30,000 KES loan she is requesting, she wants to purchase 10 bundles of maize flour, one sack of beans and cooking oil. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase 10 bundles of maize flour, one sack of beans and cooking oil

loans.name: Sok

texts.en:
Sok Y., age 58, has been cultivating rice crops on her own farmland for over ten years, in the province of Kompong Chhnang. Her husband earns a daily income by working on a fruit plantation. The couple usually generates a profit about $3.50 per day. They have given birth to seven children, all married now and most of them living separately.

Sok Y. says she is worried about the water system in her house. She always goes to her neighbor’s house when she needs to use water. It is not easy for her and her family to access water. Therefore, Sok Y. would like a loan to dig a well for her family's use. This loan will improve her living standard and make her family’s situation better. She dreams of opening a new grocery store.

loans.use: to dig a well for her family's use

loans.name: Anne

texts.en:
Anne C. is 33 years old and llives in Kakamega. She is married to Nelson. They have three children between the ages of eight and four.

She has a business of selling secondhand clothes. She has been in this business for the past nine years and has seen it grow through the years. She is applying for her second loan from KADET LTD and wants to use the money to buy more clothes to add to her stock.

Anne is very optimistic that her business will expand after she gets the loan. She hopes to open up a boutique in the future.

loans.use: to buy more clothes to add to her stock.

loans.name: María Alexandra

texts.es:
En el sitio la pila del cantón Montecristi se reúne cada quince días el Banco Comunal  Para el Futuro De la Mujer. Este lugar es muy conocido en la provincia y en el país por su rica cultura tradicional, donde se puede encontrar una gran variedad de  artesanía que son elaboradas por sus habitantes siguiendo las costumbres tradicionales.

En este lugar encontramos a la señora María, tiene 28 años de edad y mantiene una relación de unión libre de la cual tiene dos hijas de 8 y 2 años, la mayor  estudian en escuela. El marido es taxista.

Ella se dedica al comercio, tiene un local en el cual vende zapatos y sandalias de todo tipo, trabaja todos los días desde las 8h30 hasta las 17h00, nos cuenta que a veces se le hace muy difícil realizar este trabajo pero que lo hace por el bien de sus pequeñas hijas, trabaja con la ayuda de un cuñado que es quien se queda a cargo del trabajo cuando ella tiene que ir a atender  a sus hijas. Lleva 4 años con su negocio el cual  ha crecido mucho. Los productos los va a comprar a Guayaquil cada fin de mes.

Este crédito es para comprar más zapatos y sandalias  de todas las formas y modelos para surtir su negocio. Está  en el Banco Comunal hace 4 años y le gusta porque con el primer crédito ella empezó su negocio que le está brindando buenas satisfacciones.

Su sueño es tener un local más grande y propio.
texts.en:
The “Para el Futuro de la Mujer” (For Woman’s Future) communal bank meets every two weeks in La Pila, Montecristi Canton.  This place is very well known in the province and nationwide for its rich cultural tradition where one can find a wide variety of arts and crafts manufactured by its residents following traditional customs.

We met María, 28, here.  She’s in a common law relationship and has two daughters who are 8 and 2 years of age; the oldest is in school.  Her husband’s a Taxi Driver.

She is a merchant.  She has a locale where she sells shoes and sandals of all types.  She works daily from 8:30 until 5:00.  She tells us that sometimes doing the work is quite difficult but she does it for her young daughters’ sake.  She works with help from a brother-in-law who watches the store when she has to attend to her children.  She’s been in business for four years and it has grown much.  She stocks up on merchandise every end of the month in Guayaquil.

This loan is to buy more shoes and sandals in all shapes and styles to stock her business.  She’s been in the communal bank for 4 years and likes it because with the first loan she started her business that is providing good satisfaction.  Her dream is to have a larger locale of her own.

loans.use: to buy shoes and sandals.

loans.name: Ruby

texts.en:
Ruby, age 34, runs a sar-sari (variety) retail shop business in the village of Agay-ayan, Gingoog City. She sells such items as canned goods, snack foods, beverages, shampoo, soap, and biscuits in the local community. Ruby has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 11,000 PHP a month from these activities. Ruby and her husband have two school-aged children.  

In 2010, Ruby joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services. She wanted to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ruby has successfully repaid her most recent previous loan of 7,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and was employed as working capital. Ruby is now requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional canned goods and snack food items. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Ruby from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional canned goods and snack food items to offer for sale in her shop

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal “LIDERANDO LAS PALMERAS”; El banco está ubicado en el distrito D. Cusco, perteneciente a la provincia D. Cusco y departamento D. Cusco.

La socia tiene 49 años D. edad y es casada y tiene 4 hijos; La socia alterna sus actividades diarias con el negocio D. venta D. productos D. maíz y D. chuño, la socia lo trae D. lugares como Calca,pisaq y Urubamba y luego lo venD. en el mercado, ella trabaja desD. las 8:00 a.m hasta las 6:00 p.m,por medio D. este negocio la socia saca adelante  a sus hijos, la socia quiere ampliar el negocio D. venta D. maíz. La socia solicita el préstamo para comprar maíz y D. chuño al por mayor.
                                                            
 La socia está feliz por el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con los pagos D. su cuota.
texts.en:
This borrower is a member of the "Liderando Las Palmeras" community bank which is located in Cusco district, in Cusco province and department.

The borrower is 49 years old, married, and has four children.  She divides her time between her daily activities and her business selling corn and 'chuño' (a freeze-dried potato product).  She buys her products in places such as Cala, Pisaq and Urubamba and then sells them in the local market.  She works from 8.00am to 6.00pm and, through this business, she gets her children ahead in life.  The borrower would like to expand her business selling corn.  She is requesting this loan to buy corn and 'chuño' wholesale.

The borrower is happy to be receiving the loan and pledges to make her repayments on time.

loans.use: to buy corn and 'chuño' (freeze-dried potato product) wholesale

loans.name: Nueva Organización Group

texts.es:
El grupo se llama nueva organización y se integra de cinco personas y que cada uno tiene su respectiva actividad.

    Las señora quine se le timo  la entrevista se llama María del  Carmen, vive en la Rivera san Vicente de Copainala estado de Chiapas México, ella es casada y a su responsabilidad  tiene a dos hijos  y son: Víctor Habrán de  ocho años de edad y el más pequeño es Emanuel de Jesús de cinco meses de edad.

     Ella se dedica  a la elaboración de panes y solicito  el préstamo para invertirlo en la compra de ingredientes  cono son: huevo, aceite, quesos, azúcar, entre otros, para luego venderlo en la misma  localidad, en la que comenta que le va bien ya que con ello obtiene  ingresos para su hogar.

     En esta actividad se inspiro ya que también quiere apoyar su esposo con lo ingreso de la casa y así juntos sacar adelante a su familia que es lo más importante para ella, en  esta actividad lleva  nueve años y cuatro meses y le está dando resultado.

    Su más grande deseo es que con esta actividad pueda trabajar y con  el préstamo apoyarse con la compra de más ingredientes para poder trabajar y así tener sus  propios  ahorros para  salir adelante.

      Las personas que se integran en el grupo son: Corazón de Jesús invierte el préstamo en la compra de mercancía para surtir su tienda de abarrotes, la señora Rafaelita se dedica a la elaboración de panes  para luego venderlo en la misma localidad, Vivían Ibis: compra y vende ropas, Sarita: se dedica a la compra y venta de pimienta para luego venderlo en la misma región.
texts.en:
The communal bank "Nueva Organización" has five members who each have their own businesses.

María del Carmen lives in Rivera san Vicente de Copainala, in the state of Chiapas, in México.  She is married and has two children:  Víctor Habrán, 8, and her youngest,Emanuel de Jesús, 5 months.  She makes bread for a living and is taking out a loan so she can buy ingredients like: eggs, oil, sugar, cheese, and other things.  Once she has made the bread, she sells it in her neighborhood.  She says that her business is doing well and she is making money for her family.  She started selling bread because she wanted to help her husband support the family and to help her family, the most important thing to her, get ahead.  She has been doing this for nine years and four months and is seeing a return on her investment.  

Her greatest desire is to be able to work doing what she is doing.  The loan will help her to buy more ingredients for her business and enable her to have her own savings so she can get ahead.  

The members of the communal bank are: Corazón de Jesús, who will invest her loan buying merchandise to stock her grocery store, la señora Rafaelita, who bakes and sells bread in her neighborhood, Vivían Ibis who buys and sells clothing, and Sarita who buys and sells chilies in the same region.

loans.use: para pagar la compra de ingredientes como son: huevo ,, harina, leche, queso, entre otrso., para la elaboración de panes.

loans.name: Juana

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal “SUMAC  AYLLU”; el banco se encuentra ubicado en el Distrito de Huanchac en la Provincia de Cusco y Departamento de Cusco.

La socia es la Sra. Juana; la socia tiene 37 años de edad, la socia es conviviente, La socia tiene 3 hijos de 22, 19, 14; La socia tiene una chichería en su propia casa, la socia vende la famosa bebida inka elaborada a base de maíz y mediante un proceso de fermentación natural, la socia desea en esta ocasión el crédito para la compra de maíz y la elaboración de la famosa bebida de los inkas la chicha. La socia solicita el préstamo para invertir en la compra de maíz amarillo.

La socia agradece el apoyo que se le otorgara y así mismo se compromete a cumplir de manera disciplinada con los pagos de las cuotas.
texts.en:
This member belongs to the "SUMAC AYLLU" community bank, which is located in the Huanchac District in Cusco Province, Cusco Department.

The member is Señora Juana; the member is 37 years old, and lives with her partner.  The member has 3 children aged 22, 19 and 14.  The member has a chicheria in her own house, selling chicha ( a traditional drink).   The member sells the famous Incan drink which is made from a corn base through a process of natural fermentation.

The member is currently looking for the loan to invest in the purchase of yellow corn.

The member is grateful for the support which is being offered her, and similarly promises to comply in a disciplined manner with her repayments.

loans.use: to invest in the purchase of yellow corn.

loans.name: Danilo

texts.en:
Danilo is 51 years old and married to Susan. The couple is blessed with seven children. Danilo is thankful that his wife helps him to manage their rice farm. According to him, he is able to earn about 30,000 PHP every harvest season.

Danilo grows rice and has been doing this for 21 years. Due to insufficient capital, Danilo was encouraged to join ASKI and be part of their organization. He is asking for a loan of 25,000 PHP to further improve his rice farming business. He will use the loan to buy fertilizer and insecticides for his farm. He hopes that his loan request will be granted.

In the future, Danilo hopes to continue to improve his farm so that his profit will increase.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and insecticides for his farm

loans.name: Juan Angel

texts.es:
Juan, tiene 30 años de edad, es soltero, vive únicamente con su madre, él es agricultor, cultiva maíz, de la producción abastece su hogar y comercializa una parte para obtener efectivo, tiene 10 años de estar realizando estas labores y fue su madre quien inicio la enseñanza del cultivo de maíz.
Él está solicitando un préstamo un préstamo para la compra de tres sacos de fertilizantes, estos son para aplicarlos al cultivo, con la intención de obtener una mejor producción para mejorar la alimentación y los ingresos del hogar. 
Su objetivo a largo plazo es mejorar su vivienda, ya que actualmente es de adobe y quiere reconstruirla con ladrillo de cemento, también la introducción de energía eléctrica, contribuyendo así a una mejor condición de vida con su madre.
texts.en:
Juan is 30 years old, single, and lives with his mother.  He is a farmer who raises corn which he uses to feed his household and also sells part of his harvest.  He’s been doing this for 10 years, an activity he learned from his mother.

He is asking for this loan in order to buy three sacks of fertilizer to spread on his crop, so that he can improve his production and have more from which to feed his household and provide an income.

His long term goal is to make improvements to his home.  It’s currently made of adobe and he wants to reconstruct it out of cement bricks and add electricity.  This will contribute to a better quality of life for his mother.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer

loans.name: Assaad

texts.en: Assaad is a 33-year-old single man from Lebanon living with his parents. He learned the mechanic occupation when he was very young. And after gaining the needed experience, he opened his own car repair shop in 2009. He is very talented at his work, which consists of repairing vehicle’s bodies.  With his requested loan of $1,200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l, he will invest in purchasing new mechanical tools and supplies. He has a good business reputation and he is distinguished by his great customer service. His business needs many improvements and he notes that the loan will help him realize his intended objectives in a short term.

loans.use: to purchase new mechanical tools and supplies

loans.name: Juan Miguel

texts.es: Juan Miguel tiene 53 años de edad, es caficultor en pequeña escala, es casado y tiene seis hijos entre las edades de 17 y 5 años, y junto a su familia reside en la comunidad de El Guineo en el municipio de Patuca. Don Juan inició a dedicarse al cultivo de café gracias a que uno de sus cuñados le hizo un pequeño prestamo de dinero y tambien le regalara una area de tierra, tiene 20 años de dedicarse a este cultivo y el manejo lo aprendió de su padre ya que tambien se dedicaba a los mismo. Don Juan se siente muy agradecido con su cuñado porque gracias a él ahora tiene su propio negocio y tiene una entrada de dinero para sostener a su familia. Su desventaja es que la pequeña finca no esta tecnificada y eso le provoca costos adicionales y el peligro de las plagas es un verdadero dolor de cabeza. Pero su ventaja es que el café es un producto bastante comercializable y una vez que sale la produccion la vende rapido. El prestamo que esta solicitando en esta ocasion lo necesita para comprar melaza, fertilizantes, y pagar la mano de obra por la chapia de la tierra. Su meta es llegar a tener 10 mz de tierra cultivada y con el apoyo de este prestamo poco a poco lo irá logrando. Este es el primer ciclo de don Juan en FAMA y espera cumplir con el compromiso de sus pagos al dia.
texts.en:
Juan Miguel is 53 and a small scale coffee grower. He is married and has six children, from 5 to 17 years old. Together with his family he lives in El Guineo neighborhood in Patuca municipality. Juan Miguel began growing coffee thanks to one of his brothers-in- law who gave him a gift of a plot of land and provided him with a small loan. He has spent 20 years cultivating coffee, a task he learned how to do from his father who is himself a small coffee grower. 

Juan is very grateful to his brother-in-law because, thanks to him, he now has his own business and an income to support his family. He feels at a  disadvantage in that his small farm is not mechanized, which causes him to incur additional costs, and the danger of pest infestations is a real headache. However, he feels he has an advantage in that coffee is a very marketable product and once it is harvested he can sell it quickly. He is requesting this loan to buy weed killer, fertilizer and to pay a labor force to clear the land. His goal is to eventually have 10 mz. of land (one manzana = approximately 1.68 acres) under cultivation and with the support of this loan he will be able to achieve this, little by little . This is Juan’s first loan cycle at FAMA and he expects to fulfill his commitment to make all his payments on time.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and weed killer and to pay laborers.

loans.name: Tarcila

texts.en:
Tarcila is 61 years old and married with seven children. She earns a living by farming rice in the Philippines. Tarcila is borrowing 15,000 PHP through Kiva partner, NWTF, to buy fertilizers and other farm supplies.
Tarcila has been farming rice for 20 years and also earns additional income from fishing and buying and selling charcoal. She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and other farm supplies.

loans.name: Napoleon

texts.es:
Napoleón, vive con su esposa y trabajan juntos en la venta de granos básicos, no tienen un horario fijo para atender el negocio, y por el momento quiere compra mercadería para aumentar el inventario.
El está solicitando un préstamo para comprar maíz, ya que quieren tener suficiente para un largo periodo, ya que sus clientes lo demandan y en este momento se puede comprar a mejor precio.
Don Napoleón quiere continuar trabajando para aumentar cada día el negocio, la clientela y las ganancias.
texts.en:
Napoleon lives with his wife and they work together selling staple grains.  They don't have a set schedule to see to their business and at the moment they want to buy merchandise to increase their inventory.

He is asking for a loan to buy corn, as they want to have enough for a long period of time since their customers demand it and right now they can buy it at a good price.

Napoleon wants to keep working to make his business, his clientele, and his earnings grow every day.

loans.use: to buy corn to sell

loans.name: Theogene

texts.en:
Theogene is 31 years old and married with two children between 3 months and 4 years old. Theogene owns a business selling clothes for men. This is his fifth successful year in this business and the hours of his work are from 6 am to 5 pm every day. 

Theogene has requested a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to increase his clothes business. This will allow him to purchase various clothes for men to resell. With any profits, he will be able to build a secure future for his business as well as for his family and he will be able to reinvest in his business.

loans.use: To purchase various clothes for men

loans.name: Kayiteuli Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité est créé le 08 MAI 2001. Il  est  constitué de 10 femmes qui habitent le même quartier. Leur activité principale est le commerce.

Madame Diocko qui est à la droite de la photo levant la main est responsable de groupe. Elle est âgée de 68 ans. Elle est mariée et mère de huit enfants. Elle a aussi en sa charge sept autre enfants confié par ses parents.

Elle s’active dans la vente de produits pharmacetique locaux. Elle a une bonne expérience dans ce domaine d’activité, qu'elle pratique depuis plus de 15 ans.

Ce prêt lui permettra de renforcer son capital et de mieux développer  ses activités.

Les profits lui permettront d’améliorer les conditions de vie de la famille (santé, nourriture, habillement etc.…).
texts.en:
The Kayiteuli solidarity group was created on the 8th of May, 2001. It is made of up 10 women who are all retailers and all live in the same area,

Diocko, on the right of the picture with her hand raised, is the group's leader. She is 68 years old, married and the mother of 8 children. She is also responsible for 7 more children which her parents have placed in her care.

Diocko is an experienced retailer who has been selling local pharmaceutical products for over 15 years. This loan will increase her working capital and allow her to restock and develop her business activities. She will use the profits from her business to improve her family's living conditions by buying food and new clothing, paying medical expenses, etc.

loans.use: to buy local pharmaceutical products for resale.

loans.name: Ke

texts.en:
Mrs. Ke is 68 years old and lives in the Baray district of Kampong Tom province, Cambodia. She earns a living by growing vegetable plants, but the profit is barely enough to cover her daily costs. She is a widow woman and a responsible mother of six children. Her elder son, Meas, also works hard to support the family, especially his young brothers and sisters who are in the age of studying.  He uses his buffalo to haul firewood for selling through the village and local markets of the province.

Ke would like to ask for some funds from Kiva, a longstanding partner of HKL, to buy a plot of land to grow more vegetable plants as well as rice crops. She tells us that this loan will help partially satisfy the family’s needs. She is grateful to all contributors to this fund, and she claims that she won’t be late to pay back to lenders.

loans.use: to buy a plot of land to grow more vegetable plants as well as rice crops.

loans.name: Marites

texts.en:
As a married mother of six children, Marites works hard to support her family.

She has a fish selling business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from selling food. Marites is borrowing PHP 11000 through NWTF to buy fish to sell in her food stall.

Marites has been sustaining her business activities through her past three loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream of saving money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy fish to sell in her food stall.

loans.name: Edna

texts.en:
Edna is originally from Sto. Domingo province of Isabela and has been in the beauty salon business for more than 5 years. The welcoming environment of the salon pulls in customers of every ethnicity, from the lower class to the upper middle class. Edna says her clients come from as far as other communities to experience her services. Those services include, but are limited to hair extensions and styling. This loan will allow Edna to purchase materials needed for her shop, which will help her generate additional income. 

In the future, she hopes that someday she can expand her business to provide for the needs of her family.

loans.use: to buy scissors, powder, clips and other items needed for her salon

loans.name: Seda

texts.en: Seda is engaged in an agricultural business. She has been successfully managing the business for thirteen years and has created a sustainable basis to enlarge it. With the requested loan, Seda plans to purchase a cow and a calf. Increase of the livestock will allow Seda to get more income and improve her family's living conditions. Seda lives together with her husband and one child.

loans.use: to purchase a cow and a calf

loans.name: Conception

texts.en:
This is Conception, 55, a resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. Her husband is Rolando, a vendor. She and her husband manage their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.  

Conception maintains a direct selling business. She sells clothing, footwear, undergarments, cosmetics and other products through the popular direct selling brands like Avon, Fuller life, Natasha, Boardwalk, Marikina Shoe Exchange, and other direct selling brands. A customers order is bought in cash by the dealer and then given to the customer with a one-month-to-pay credit. Dealer’s prices are lower than those in the catalogue, and these are the profits that dealers are investing on as their income. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of 2000 Philippine Pesos (PHP) in sales every week.

To help her continue operations of her business, Conception is requesting a PHP23,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy merchandise and to fill the orders for her customers. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Conception hopes to grow her business in the coming years. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and where he can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for inventory items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Naimchon

texts.ru: Наимчон парень 27 лет, пока не женат, единственный сын в семье. Он проживает вместе с родителями. Работает в городской сауне, его дохода хватает на жизнь, но на крупные семейные расходы не может накопить. Поэтому он решил получить кредит на ремонт дома, у него протекает крыша, и он хочет обновить шифер крыши. Он на снимке в день выдачи, рад получению запрашиваемой суммы.
texts.en: Naimchon is a 27 year-old young man, not yet married and is the only son in his family.  He lives with his parents.  Naimchon works at the city sauna and has enough income for living, but is unable to save for big family expenses.  This is why he decided to obtain a loan to repair his house that has a leaking roof.  Naimchon wants to replace the roof slate.  The photograph shows him on the disbursement day, happy to obtain the requested sum.

loans.use: For roof repairs at home

loans.name: Maiyum

texts.en: Maiyum, 45, is married and resides in Kampong Chnang Province. Maiyum and her husband sell Chinese noodles and coffee. Maiyum is requesting a loan of US $1000 to purchase clothes for her daughter to sell and expand her business. In the future, Maiyum would like to use her additional income to send her children to a good school. This will be her first loan from KREDIT, a longstanding Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy clothes for her daughter to sell.

loans.name: La Amistad Group

texts.es: Jeni es integrante de la Alcancía Comunal “La Amistad” y está conformado por 10 socios, dicho grupo tiene 08 meses trabajando con el Programa- Prosperidad. Jeni tiene 41 años de edad es casada y tiene  02 hijos, actualmente sigue apoyando al menor de ellos, ella se dedica a la compra y venta de miel de abejas, su padre fue quien la motivo a emprender su propio negocio, ya que es él quien le abastece de dicho producto, también brinda servicio de limpieza de donde obtiene una ingreso mas para su hogar, con su trabajo y esfuerzo Jeni ha logrado mejorar su vivienda y actualmente apoyar a su menor hija en sus estudios. A futuro a Jeni le gustaría poner una bodega en su domicilio donde pueda ofrecer  productos de primera necesidad. En esta oportunidad  solicito el crédito para la compra de miel de abeja y así poder entregar sus pedidos a tiempo. La Alcancía Comunal "La Amistad" estan agradecidos con el crédito brindado. Adjuntamos la fotografía de Reymundo y Maruja.
texts.en: Jeni is a member of the "La Amistad" (friendship) Community Bank which is made up of 10 members. Said group has eight months working with the Prosperity Program. Jeni is 41 years old, is married and has two children. Currently she continues to support the youngest of them. She is dedicated to buying and selling bee honey. Her father motivated her to start her own business since he supplies this product. She also provides a cleaning service from which she obtains more income for her home. With her work and effort Jeni has managed to improve her house and currently supports her youngest daughter in her studies. In the future, Jeni would like to start a bodega in her house where she can offer basic necessity products. At this time she is requesting a loan for the purchase of bee honey and, in this way, to be able to deliver her orders on time. "La Amistad" Community Bank is thankful for the loan provided. We are attaching the photos of Reymundo and Maruja.

loans.use: to purchase bee honey.

loans.name: Mansata 's Group

texts.fr:
Ce groupe est composé de femmes très actives dans ce banc villageois créé le  28 Mai 2002. Elles sont toutes issues du même quartier et ont une bonne entente entre elles du fait de 23 cycles passés ensemble. Elles ont comme activité principale le petit commerce.

Madame Mansata  (assise à l’extrême droite avec la main droite levée), est l’emprunteuse vedette du groupe,  âgée de 43 ans, elle est mariée et mère de sept enfants  (04 garçons et 03 filles). Elle fait de la transformation de pâte d’arachide. Elle achète le sac de graines non décortiqués et fait la transformation pour ainsi revendre le produit fini par seau de 20 et 5 kg selon les besoins du client.

Avec ce prêt elle compte s’approvisionner pour 15 sacs de graines non décortiqués pour la transformation et la vente.

Les bénéfices lui servent d’épargne d’une part et d’autre par à soutenir son mari dans la dépense quotidienne.
texts.en:
This group is made up of 25 women, who are very active in this Banc Villageois, established on May 28th, 20022. They all come from the same neighborhood and get on well, as they have already received 23 loans together. Their main business is retail.

Mrs. Mansata (sitting on the far right and raising her hand in the photograph) is the group's featured borrower. She's 43 years old, married, and the mother of seven children, four boys and three girls.

She transforms peanuts into peanut paste. She buys sacks of unshelled peanuts and transform them in peanut paste, that she resells in buckets of five or twenty kilos, depending on the customer's needs.

With this loan, she intends to buy 15 sacks of unshelled peanuts to transform and sell. The profits will be used in part to build up her savings, and in part to help her husband cover daily expenses.

loans.use: to buy 15 sacks of unshelled peanuts to transform into peanut paste

loans.name: Rose's Group

texts.en:
Rose, featured in the above picture, is representing her farming group formed by 9 farmers in Chwele District, Kenya. She is 43 years old and a married mother of 6 children, often described as a very reliable person. 

Although Rose has been a farmer for 15 years, she is new to One Acre Fund and decided to join this year because she really wanted to get the best quality fertilizer and hybrid seeds. Even though she is new to the program, Rose wanted to represent her group because she wanted to help more farmers. With the profits earned from this season’s harvest, Rose hopes to be able to send her children to school.

With this loan, the group will receive farming inputs to plant a total of 3 acres of land. They will also receive a total of 3 solar lights, as, even though Rose decided not to, some of the farmers in the group will be purchasing a solar light as part of their loan package."

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seeds and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize

loans.name: Kaemorak

texts.en:
W. Kaemorak is married and lives with his wife and three children in the house they built quickly after moving into their new village. He started the works two weeks ago but needs additional funds to complete the improvement he planed. He is doing everything alone, “by my own” he said in English.

W. Kaemorak speaks a little English. He learnt when driving foreigners on his moto-taxi. He would like to learn more but his wife say he is too old now. “English is for fresh brains”, she said. Their two youngest children, 14 and 5 years old, are going to school six days a week.

As for the family resources, the moto taxi breeds around 12,000 Riel ($3) per day. Kaemorak’s wife can make around 10,000 Riel ($2.5) in sewing trousers and repairing clothes on her machine at home. The family eldest son is employed as a security guard in a night club in Phnom Penh. He makes $80 per month and works at night.

loans.use: Finish to build his house

loans.name: Leni

texts.en:
L. is 28 years old, and is married with three children aged 9, 4 and 1. The first two are boys while the last one is a girl. Her husband, Cecep. is an unskilled temporary worker in a small factory, earning $80 per month. L. and her family live in a very simple wooden house with an earthen floor.

To supplement her husband’s income, L. sells household goods like sugar, coffee, soap, washing powder, toothpaste and other toiletries by going around the village on foot and carrying two large plastic bags. Her present working capital is only $65 dollars, on which she earns only $20 a month. With the additional working capital from MBK of $55, she can buy more goods to sell around the houses, and thus more or less double her income. L. very much wants to earn more money for her children’s education, and to give them a better life than she grew up with.

loans.use: Purchase household goods for resale around the village

loans.name: Eseta

texts.en: Eseta L. is thirty–eight years of age and is from the village of Sataoa.  She has two children.  Her small business project is running a banana plantation.  There are many different types of bananas that grow well in Samoa and bananas are a staple of the local diet.  Eseta works from morning till evening to clear brush, weed and plant bananas.  Her husband also believes in the business and helps when he can.  Eseta takes her bananas to the local markets and sells them there.  The income from Eseta’s banana sales are crucial to providing for the basic needs of her family, and she is anxious to invest further in her business.  With a loan, she hopes to purchase natural fertilizers that can improve her crop yield as well as materials to build a fence around her plantation.

loans.use: Purchase fertilizer and fencing material

texts.en: Mrs. H. is 40 years old and her husband is 42. They have four children, two sons and two daughters, between the ages of 17 and 6. All of them go to school. They live in Nghe An, a rural province in the upper center of Vietnam. Mrs. H.'s husband is a construction worker and he has no regular income. Sometimes he's away for projects far away and sometimes he's at home. To provide extra income, Mrs. H. runs a farm. She has rice fields, grows groundnuts, and has a fish pond. She wants to buy cows so she can plough her fields, which will make the work easier. She just sold her breeding pigs for $ 200.

loans.use: to buy cows for her farm

loans.name: Miguel

texts.en:
Miguel has 7 years' experience in selling seafood, which he learned from his father who took him to work with him from a very young age. Miguel learned and mastered the trade as he gained more experience. He decided to work on his own since he was married and needed to be able to cover the expenses for his household. He works from 4 am to 11 am every day with his wife and a relative who helps them remove the meat from crabs so that later it can be put into tubs and sold.

Miguel wants a loan to be able to invest in different types of seafood. This is his second loan with our program. He hopes that he can give his brother work with the income generated. Miguel is married, 23 years old, and has a daughter six months old. He hopes to be able to earn enough to have his own home, since he now lives with his parents.

loans.use: Invest in other types of seafood

loans.name: Maruf

texts.ru:
Maruf I. is 35 years old, is married and has 3 children. Maruf’s wife helps him in the business and the children are in school. Maruf has been selling food for 15 years now. From a young age he helped his mother in her business and gained experience. When he found out about MicroInvest, Maruf decided to take out a loan and increased his inventory. After getting and fully using a loan he expanded his product offering and expanded his place of business.

Maruf plans to use the new loan to open an additional business location, where his wife will handle the sales.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer.

Исмоилов Маъруфчон 35лет, женат, имеет троих детей. Жена помогает мужу в торговле, дети учатся в школе. Маъруфчон занимается продажей продуктов питания, вот уже 15лет. С малых лет он помогал, матери в торговле и этим набрал опыт. Узнав о программе МЗФ «Микроинвест» он решил получить займ и тем самым увеличить товарооборот. После получения займа и целевого использования он увеличил ассортимент товара, расширил место деятельности. В дальнейшем планирует открыть ещё одно место для торговли, где будет торговать его жена.

loans.use: to open a new business location for his wife

loans.name: Favour

texts.en: Favour is an industrious woman. She has been in the business for over 5 years. Her poly business has brought comfort to her family. She produces polyethylene bags and supply to her customer in her community. She is a LAPO member. She hopes to get the loan amount of US$ 250 to buy more equipment and material for production of bags for sale. She thanks you.

loans.use: To make more polyethylene bags for sale

loans.name: Catherine's Group

texts.en:
Catherine K. wants to enlarge her business by buying another dryer. With the loan, Catherine will also buy a piece of land where she can construct a permanent building for her business.

Background on BRAC and BRAC Uganda

BRAC (Building Resources Across Communities) is a development organization that began operations in Bangladesh as a small-scale relief and rehabilitation project in 1972 to help the country overcome the devastation and trauma of the liberation war and focused on resettling refugees returning from India. Today, BRAC has emerged as an independent, virtually self-financed paradigm in sustainable human development. It is one of the largest Southern development organizations employing over 100,000 people, 61% of which are women, and working with the twin objectives of poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor. Diagnosing poverty in human terms and recognizing its multifaceted nature, BRAC approaches poverty alleviation with a holistic approach.

The successes of BRAC in the international development arena have stimulated a series of discussions, both with African delegations, who have visited BRAC programs, and with donors who work in Asia and Africa. Both the African countries and the donors have encouraged BRAC to join the development campaign in Africa to achieve the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) and more recently to join the campaign of “ending poverty”, which is an area where Africa represents the greatest global challenge.

In Uganda, BRAC registered as a Non Government Organization (NGO) in January 2006 to undertake programs in Education, Health, Water & Sanitation, Agriculture & Livestock and Microfinance. The Microfinance and Education are the pioneer programs launched in Uganda and, as of July 2007, had served 21,273 borrowers and enrolled 1,155 adolescents in its education program.

loans.use: To enlarge her business

loans.name: Nankulabye B(I) Group

texts.en:
This group has been together for seven months. Harriet and Beatrice both sell fruits and vegetables wholesale. Harriet wants to pay school fees for the children with the extra business profits. Suzan and Roy sell used clothes and want to use the loan to expand business while Aisha has a beauty salon.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To add in vegetable business

loans.name: Yon

texts.en:
Mrs. Yon P. is 37 years old and works as a teacher at Check Angre secondary school in the Takmoa district of the Kandal province. Her husband, Mr. Chhan Vanthan, is 44 years old and drives a motorcycle taxi. They have two children who are both in school. To earn a living for their family, Yon and her husband work hard everyday.

Yon is requesting $1100.00 in order to build a fifteen-room house that she can then rent to customers. She has proven to be a reliable client of HKL. And she thanks HKL for their support and promises to be accurate in her loan payment.

loans.use: To build a fifteen-room house to rent to customers

loans.name: Adnan

texts.en: Adnan is a 49-year-old man. He lives in Northern Lebanon, in Tripoli with his family. Adnan has 9 children. He distributes gaz bottles and also owns a coffee shop he wants to re-open. This is the first time he is applying for a loan at Al Majmoua. He wants to reinvest in this last mentioned business.

loans.use: to reinvest in a coffee shop

loans.name: Farida

texts.en:
Farida is 39 years old and is a widow with 3 children, ages 20, 16 and 12. Farida owns a small food store, which she started in 2000. Every day Farida works from 7am to 7pm at her shop and can earn a monthly profit of about $25 from her sales.

Farida has requested this loan to buy more food items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more food items to sell

loans.name: Sofia

texts.en:
N. Sofia has a retail shop in Najjembe trading centre that sells new clothes for men, women and children. She has had her shop for one-and-a-half years now. She is also a proud member of Mabira development group taking loans of various amounts and repaying them on time. She is married with four children between the ages of 4 to 14 years with no-one else to cater for except her parents in the village.

She would like a loan to help her buy more clothes for her shop. Her dream is to see the shop grow to selling other goods like shoes, handbags and many clothes of different makes.

loans.use: To buy clothing for men, women and children for her shop.

loans.name: Rosaline

texts.fr:
Mrs. Rosaline D. was born in Cotonou around 1970. She is married and the mother of two children, of whom one is enrolled in school and the other in an apprenticeship. She sells take-out food prepared of rice and dried beans, locally known as "Atassi," out of her home in the Adogléta neighborhood of Cotonou. She is open for business from 8 to 11 AM. She would like to upgrade her venue and make it more attractive. She would also like to increase her sales volume by not purchasing her rice and beans by the kilogram. For this reason, she is requesting a loan in the amount of US$ 475 so that she can better meet the needs of her clientele.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

Dame D. Rosaline est née vers 1970 à Cotonou. Elle est mariée et mère de deux enfants dont l’un est scolarisé et l’autre à l’apprentissage. Elle vend du repas prêt à manger fait à base du riz et du haricot communément appelé « Atassi » en son domicile à Cotonou au quartier Adogléta. Elle vend dans la matinée de 08 heures à 11 heures. Elle désire améliorer son cadre de vente et le rendre plus atrayant. Aussi, voudrait elle augmenter le volume de son activité en rompant avec l'achat du riz et du haricot au kilogramme. Pour cela, elle sollicite un prêt de 200000 F CFA pour mieux répondre aux attentes de la clientèle.

loans.use:
bolster her inventory by buying a 50kg sack of rice, 25 liters of cooking oil, 1 sack of dried beans, 1 case of macaroni/spaghetti, 1 small sack of onions, and various condiments

renforcer son stock de marchandises en achetant 1 sac de riz de 50kg, 25 litres d’huiles, 1 sac de haricot, 1 carton de macaroni spaghetti, 1 petit sac d’oignons et divers condiments

loans.name: Sak

texts.en: Mrs. Sak T. is a basketmaker in Bampong Phchoek Village in Kampong Chhnang Province. Her husband, Mr. Noeurn T., is a fisherman. They have four children, one of whom is a construction worker while two others help their mother. The last one is attending school. Mrs. Sak T.'s family now lives in old house, so she wants to build a new house in order to improve her living conditions. Mrs. Sak T. asked for a loan for this purpose. Her husband is in the photo.

loans.use: To build a new house in order to improve her living conditions.

loans.name: Djamshed

texts.ru: Олимов Джамшед родился в 1975 году. Он женат и имеет 4 иждивенцев. В городе Вахдате есть бильярдные клубы, куда часто приходят молодежь и любители бильярда. Джамшед тоже любил бильярд и начал работать смотрителем в одном из бильярдных клубов города. Работая в клубе ему понравился этот вид бизнеса и он решил открыть собственный бизнес. Часть своего дома переоборудовал под бильярдный клуб и теперь у него свои постоянные клиенты. В будущем он хочет купить еще несколько бильярдных и теннисных столов. Но до этого Джамшед хочет с помощью программы КИВА получить займ в сумме 4100 сомони и отремонтировать свой клуб.
texts.en:
Djamshed O. was born in 1975, he is married and has four dependent children. In his town of Vahdat there are many pool clubs which are often visited by young people and pool lovers. Djamshed also loves pool and started working as a watch guard in one of the local pool clubs. By working in this club he has realized that he likes this type of business and decided to start his own. He has remodeled part of his house for a pool club and he now has regular clients. In the future he wants to buy more pool and ping pong tables. But at this time Djamshed wants to get a loan of USD$1,200 (4100 somoni) with the help of Kiva to do repairs in his club.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To repair pool club inside the house

loans.name: Le Thi

texts.vi: Mrs. Le Thi H., aged 46, joined TYM Fund in 2003. At present, in addition to farming, her family invests in groundnut trading. Every day with the assistance of her husband and two grown-up children, her business goes on well and generates an income of VND 3 million. For the next loan cycle, she wants to borrow VND 13 million to invest more in groundnut trading to increase her family's economy.
texts.en:
Note: the original description is in English.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to invest more in groundnut trading

loans.name: Nelvith

texts.es:
La señora Nelvith pertenece al Banco Comunal “Las Margaritas” y vive en la Región San Martín, Provincia El Dorado, distrito D. Agua Blanca. Se dedica a la venta D. comida tipo menú y su negocio está ubicado en su casa, Jr. Oscar R. Benavides S/N, lugar donD. acuden diariamente sus comensales, que son moradores D. su localidad y visitantes D. otros lugares. 

Con este crédito D. S/.2,000, el cual será cancelado en 6 meses, comprará arroz, azúcar en saco, aceite en galón, y otros ingredientes que necesita para la preparación diaria D. los platos que oferta a sus clientes como verduras, carnes (D. res, cerdo, pollo y pescado), además quiere comprar animales para criar en su huerta tales como cerdos, gallinas, pollos, los cuales son animales que utiliza en la preparación D. sus platos. En vista que no hay un mercado en donD. encuentran D. todo tiene que salir a comprar a la ciudad mas cercana.

La señora Nelvith tiene 45 años D. edad, vive con su esposo y sus 03 hijos que aún depenD. D. ella y cuenta con su familia quienes la apoyan en las actividades D. su negocio. Es una mujer decidida, alegre y buena administradora. Tiene como meta comprar una refrigeradora para implementar su negocio con al venta D. bebidas heladas, así como también mejorar su  local y brindar una buena atención a sus clientes.
texts.en:
Nelvith belongs to the Las Margaritas community bank and lives in the Agua Blanca district of El Dorado province in San Martín. She has a restaurant business where she specializes in serving a set meal each day, and her establishment is located in her home in the Benavides neighborhood. Her diners—local residents and visitors from elsewhere—gather there each day. With this six-month loan of $675 (2,000 nuevos soles), Nelvith will buy rice, sugar by the sack, oil by the gallon, and other ingredients needed for preparing the dishes she serves her customers on a daily basis, ingredients like vegetables and meat (beef, pork, chicken and fish). In addition, she wants to purchase animals to raise in her field—like pigs, hens, and chickens—those that she uses in the preparation of her meals. Since there is no (local) marketplace in which all this can be found, she has to go to the nearest town to shop. Nelvith is 45 years old, and resides with her husband and three children, who still live at home. She counts on her family to help with the operation of the restaurant. Nelvith is a resolute woman, cheerful and a good manager. Her goal is to purchase a refrigerator so she can branch out into the sale of chilled beverages, improve her establishment and better attend to her customers.

Translated from Spanish by Joyce ., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of rice, sugar, oil and other ingredients

location.town: Agua Blanca - El Dorado - San Martín

loans.name: María Guadalupe

texts.es:
La señora María se dedica a la venta de joyería desde hace ya más de 3 años;  esté negocio y su empleo de enfermera son su ingreso familiar ya que ella es madre soltera. Bajo su responsabilidad tiene un hijo que aún está estudiando.
Al negocio de la joyería de la señora María le está haciendo falta mercancía, ya que como ella trabaja sobre pedido, tiene varias clientes que le han solicitado artículos de joyería y debe comprarlos para revenderlos y obtener ganancias.
texts.en:
Maria is a single mother whose son is still in school. She is solely responsible for bringing in the household income, so for more than three years now, in addition to her job as a nurse, she has also dedicated herself to the sale of jewelery. Her enterprise, however, is lacking supplies. Many clients have ordered jewelery from her, but she lacks the materials to fill these orders and thus, turn a profit.

Translated from Spanish by Sara Sultan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For the purchase of jewelry supplies

loans.name: Roth

texts.en:
Roth C., 43, lives with her old mother and earns income selling groceries and rice noodles. She sells rice noodles called “Nom Banchok." They are used to prepare one of the favorite dishes in Cambodia and are typically served with different kinds of vegetables and herbs, including mint, banana blossoms, string beans, English cucumber, and mung bean sprouts. Rice noodles can also be used in two types of local soups - green and red soup. 
On average, Roth Chavin makes US$5 a day. At present, she needs a loan of US$400 to be able to increase her grocery inventory to respond to the increasing demand.

loans.use: Increase in inventory

loans.name: Elvira

texts.en:
Elvira is a thrity-two year old married mother of two children.  She lives in the Callería district in the region of Ucayali in eastern Peru.  Elvira lives with her family in the city of Pucallpa, the capital of the Ucayali region and a bustling transportation hub in the area.

Elvira’s business is selling clothing and she has been supporting her business for four years with the help of loans from Manuela Ramos.  Elvira is a member of the Mujeres Emprendedoras, or “Women Entrepreneurs” communal bank.

Elvira is requesting 3,000 Nuevo Soles to fund the purchase of one large sack of clothing that she will offer for resale.  She will repay this loan within six months.  She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To purchase one large sack of clothing that she will offer for resale

loans.name: Rosa Ana

texts.es:
Rosa es socia del Bancomunal Las Orquídeas.
Rosa es separada, tiene 47 años, dos hijos de 28 y 27 años ambos estudian y trabajan. 
Empezó hace veinte años a cosiendo ropa,  dando servicio de confección a talleres de costura, esto le trajo muchos dolores en su columna. Decidió cambiar de  actividad empezó a trabajaba  en casa de una señora que daba menús a varias  fabricas, la señora falleció de un momento a otro, ella se hizo cargo del negocio, pero lo traslado a su casa. También cada mes viaja al norte para traer zapatos de Trujillo.

Desde que esta en Finca tiene mas ingresos económicos, aprendió a invertir, a  ahorrar ha podido comprar su casa hace tres años. 
Necesita un préstamo de 800 soles, para invertirlo en la compra de víveres, para preparar el menú, arroz, fideos, aceite y traer zapatos del norte de Perú.
El sueño de Rosa es tener un restauran y un taller de confecciones.
texts.en:
Rosa is a member of the Las Orquídeas Community Bank. She is 47 years old, separated, and has two children who are 28 and 27 years old, and who both study and work. She started sewing clothing twenty years ago, offering her services to sewing workshops. This type of work caused her great pain in her back. She decided to change jobs, and started to work in the house of a lady who provided lunchtime meals to various factories. This lady died suddenly, and Rosa took charge of the business, moving it to her home. Additionally, each month she travels to the north to bring back shoes from Trujillo. Since she has worked with Finca she has increased her income, learned to invest and save, and was able to buy her own home three years ago. She is seeking a loan of 800 soles to buy food supplies such as rice, noodles and oil in order to prepare the meals, and also to buy shoes in the north of Peru. Rosa's dream is to own a restaurant and a dressmaking workshop.

Translated from Spanish by Sally Bolton, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase food supplies to prepare meals for sale, and to buy shoes in the north of Peru

loans.name: Rocío

texts.es: Rocío tiene 23 años, vive con su esposo y su hijo de 2 años en una casa arrendada. Se dedica a la venta de balones de gas desde hace un año, pero hace 4 meses decidió abrir una distribuidora en una ciudad cercana debido al comercio más activo que existe en ese lugar. Rocío arrendó un local donde vive momentáneamente y a la vez vende sus balones de gas para uso doméstico, adicionalmente vende comida a los trabajadores  de una empresa de refinería de metales, lo cual significa un ingreso más. Lo bueno es que ella cuenta con el apoyo incondicional de su madre que la apoya en el cuidado de su pequeño hijo mientras ella trabaja en su establecimiento, es por ello que el deseo de Rocío es crecer en este negocio para poder  contratar personal en le reparto de los balones de gas para tener más tiempo para atender a su pequeño. Es la segunda vez que tiene un préstamo con MFP, ella fue invitada a integrar el banco comunal y demostró que era responsable en sus pagos, además se siente muy bien con los integrantes de su grupo porque para ella ha sido un espacio de amistad. El dinero que solicita es para comprar más balones de gas, que en promedio están a 80 soles cada uno, comprará 25.
texts.en:
Rocío is 23 years old and lives with her husband and 2-year-old son in a rented house. For the last year she has sold gas bottles, and four months ago she decided to move her business to a nearby city where there is potential for more sales. Rocío rented a place to live and from there sells gas bottles for home use. She also sells food to workers from a local metal refinery, which is an additional source of income. Rocío is lucky to have the unconditional support of her mother, who takes care of her son while she works. Rocío wants her business to grow so that she can hire employees to help sell the gas bottles so that she can have more time with her son.

This is Rocío's second loan from Kiva's partner Microfinanzas PRISMA, and she has been invited to become a member of the community bank. She has been responsible in her repayments and she enjoys being a part of the group, which for her is a place of friendship.

Rocío will use the money from the loan to purchase more gas bottles, which cost an average of 80 Peruvian nuevos soles (US $25). She will purchase 25 of them.

Translated from Spanish by Kris Vickery, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase her merchandise

loans.name: Van

texts.en: Mrs. Van R. is 63 years old and she lives in Dey Et Kos Poss village in Kandal province. She is a vegetable seller in the local market. Since her business is doing well, she wants to expand it by purchasing more vegetables to resell to earn more income. Mrs. Van R. is a widow with six children who are blacksmiths.

loans.use: Purchasing more vegetables to resell to earn more income.

loans.name: Farida's Group

texts.en:
Farida is the group leader of the Farida group. The four members of this group all want to expand their businesses. Farida wants to take a loan for her tailoring business; Abinulyamin's loan is for his tire repairing shop; Jamila wants to take a loan for her embroidery business; M. Halem's loan is for his car workshop.

They have requested a group loan of 56000 Afghani for the term of ten months. The group send many thanks to Kiva lenders for supporting entrepreneurs around the world.

loans.use: To progress their businesses

loans.name: Evans

texts.en: Evans sells phone accessories and rechargeable phone cards. He is thirty years old and single with no children. He hopes for the loan of $675 to purchase more phone accessories and rechargeable phone cards to sell. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy more phone accessories and rechargeable phone cards to sell

loans.name: Luisa

texts.es:
Luisa es socia del Bancomunal Las Gitanas.
Luisa es separada  tiene 65 años, tres hijos de 38, 34 y  24 años.
Luisa hace dulces kékes, tamales para reuniones especiales y también vende productos de belleza por catalogo.
Luisa necesita un préstamo de 1000 soles, para la compra de productos de Belleza por catalogo por el día de la madre.
Desde que esta en Finca aprendió ahorrar, le gustan las reuniones, tiene amigas aprende más de negocio.
El sueño de Luisa es salir adelante y viajar al extranjero para ver a su hija, no la ve más de quince años.
texts.en:
Luisa is a member of Las Gitanas community bank. Luisa, 65, is separated; she has three children ages 38, 34, and 24. Luisa makes sweet kékes (a typical Peruvian pastry) and tamales for special gatherings. She also sells beauty products by catalog. Luisa needs a loan for 1,000 PEN to buy beauty products by catalog for Mother’s Day. Since she has been with Finca, she has learned to save. She likes the meetings, she has friends, and she learns more about business. Luisa’s dreams are to get ahead and to travel abroad to see her daughter whom she has not seen for fifteen years.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy beauty products by catalog for Mother’s Day.

loans.name: Pech's Group

texts.en:
This group of borrowers consists of five women. Its leader, S., is age 30, married with three children who are studying in the local public school.
