loans.use: To buy stocks for his restaurant (sugar and rice)

loans.name: Teofila

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal "JUNTOS DE LA MANO"; El banco esta situado en el Distrito de Iscuchaca en la Provincia de Anta perteneciente al Departamento de Cusco.

La socia es la Sra. Teofila; ella tiene 46 años de edad, la socia es viuda y tiene 6 hijos la socia se dedica  la compra y venta de animales menores y ala compra y venta de granos como maíz en los diferentes tipos, habas secas, porotos, frejoles, cebada, trigo y otros. La socia en esta ocasión desea invertir el prestamo en la compra de productos secos como los mencionados antes para implementar su mercaderia.

La socia agradece el credito y se compromete a cumplir con los pagos en el tiempo establecido.
texts.en:
Introducing Teofila, a member of “JUNTOS DE LA MANO" (Holding Hands), a Communal Bank located in Iscuchaca, a district of the Anta province in the Cusco department.

Teofila is 46 years old, she is a widow and she has 6 children. She engages in buying and selling small animals and in buying and selling grains such as various varieties of maize, dried broad beans, green beans, lima beans, barley and wheat. In this occasion she wants to invest the loan in the purchase of dried goods such as the aforementioned ones in order to supply her stock.

She is thankful for the loan and she commits to complying with the repayment of her dues in the agreed time.

loans.use: To buy products such as maize, dried broad beans, green beans, lima beans, barley and wheat.

loans.name: Specioza

texts.en:
This 37-year-old married woman used the previous loan to buy crates of beer for resale. With the profits, Specioza has been able to pay school fees for her children and also expand her bar. 

She still has challenges of inadequate capital to meet the increasing demand. Her dream is to have a well-stocked bar and restaurant. Specioza intends to buy beer for resale with this loan.

loans.use: to buy beer for resale.

loans.name: Flora

texts.en:
Flora is 60 years old and runs a small business operating a Sari-sari store, selling canned goods, noodles, soda, soap, toiletries, coffee and sugar. She lives in Dimiao, a town in the province of Bohol. Her husband drives a motorcycle to supplement the income that she is getting from the Sari-sari store.
Flora has requested a loan from CEVI to expand her business. With the loan, she would like to purchase more goods to sell such as canned sardines,  beef loaf, shampoo, bath soap, milk, coffee, sugar,  match, biscuits, cigarettes, soft drinks and liquor. Her profit will be primarily for food and education of her children.

loans.use: to buy canned sardines,  beef loaf, shampoo, bath soap, milk, coffee, sugar,  match,  biscuits, cigarettes, soft drinks and liquor

loans.name: Renukavva

texts.en:
Ms.Renukavva Y.M. - aged 30 years, has two daughters. She was ill literate and now able to read and write by attending night school in her small village called Madabhavi in Mudhol taluka of Bagalkot district in Karnataka, India.  Now she is working as a farm labor for Rs.40/- day. She would like to purchase one she buffalo. By rearing this buffalo she will be able to get about 12-15 liters milk per day and by which she will be able to earn an amount of Rs.125/- to Rs.150/- per day with a net profit of Rs.75/- to Rs.100/- per day. To by this she bufellow she requires a loan amount of Rs.15000/-. Loan repayment will be completed in 2 years and installment will paid every month.

*July 2006 exchange rate is 46 rupees to the US
dollar

loans.use: Purchasing a she-buffalo

loans.name: Carlos

texts.en:
Carlos has 18 years of experience in his field. He worked alongside his father from the time he was young. He travels through neighborhoods buying used items house to house. He buys and fixes the items so that he can sell them at low prices in the poorer areas. He goes out in the streets looking for goods from 8 am to 2 pm. The business has allowed him to support his family and make some repairs to his home.

He needs the loan to buy used items in bulk, so that he can fix and sell them.

Carlos was born in Guayaquil He is 32 years old with 3 children, all still in school. His wife helps him around the house. At the moment they do not own their own home. They are a very humble and hardworking couple who persevere to get ahead. Their dream is that their children finish school and that their business grows, since it is the sole source of income for the family.

Translated by Erin Corcoran, Kiva volunteer.

Carlos tiene una experiencia de 18 años en esta actividad, desde joven se dedicó a trabajar junto a su padre. El negocio de él es recorrer las casas y comprar artefactos y artículos usados. Él compra y los arregla para poder venderlos a precios baratos para ciertas zonas pobres. Él sale a recorrer las calles de 8:00AM a 2:00PM. El negocio le ha permitido mantener a la familia y hacer ciertos arreglos en la casa.

Él necesita el préstamo para comprar en lote sus artefactos y artículos para arreglarlos.

Carlos nació en Guayaquil. Tiene 32 años. Con 3 hijos todavía en la escuela. Su esposa le ayuda en su hogar. Actualmente todavía no tienen casa propia. Ellos son una pareja muy humilde y trabajadora que luchan por seguir adelante. Su sueño es que sus hijos estudien y que su negocio crezca porque es su única fuente de ingresos para el hogar.

loans.use: Buy used goods in bulk to repair and resell

loans.name: Polima

texts.en: Polima is a talented woman with four lovely children.  She makes several products that she sells to the local villagers – a delicious coconut/tapioca drink, cakes, buns and donuts.  She admits that making enough of these products each day to satisfy her customer base is very hard work, but her family and friends are very supportive of her efforts to be a successful entrepreneur.  Polima sells her goods through local shops and just by walking around in her village with a basket of goods.  Polima’s business income is critical to supporting the needs of her family and she is committing to continuing to invest in the business.  A loan will give Polima the capital to purchase supplies in bulk (and thus at a better rate) and ensure a consistent supply of her delights for the local villagers.

loans.use: :  Buy bulk products to make drinks and baked goods

loans.name: Yengibar

texts.en: Yengibar I. is 41, is married, and has three children. Since 1999 he has been running his own business, a small farm consisting of cows and calves. Now he is going to broaden his business and purchase a sheep herd. For this purpose he has applied for a loan of $1,200 USD.

loans.use: To purchase a sheep herd

loans.name: Lucila

texts.es:
Description of theBusiness

Lucila has had a little Pharmacy practice for the last four years. She attends to her customers every day of the week from 8 am until 10 pm. Lucila sends medications such as: pills, painkillers, liquid serums, and various antibiotics.

Use of the Loan

Lucila is asking for a loan in order to purchase medications in accordance with her customers' demands. She also needs to purchase a sliding door to increase the security of her practice.

Personal Descripton

Lucila is 39 years old and has a 12 year old son. Her husband work as a vendor of shoes and supports her store. She desires to continue building her life and knows that in order to do this, she must expand her Pharmacy practice. Then, she would be have better security at home.

Translated from Spanish by Chloé Tuot, a Kiva Volunteer.

Descripción del Negocio

Lucila tiene pequeño negocio de farmacia desde hace 4 años. Atiende a sus clientes todos los días de la semana de 8: AM 22 PM . Lucila vende medicamentos como: Pastillas Apronax, Pankreoflac, Ranitidina, Suero Oral, Antibióticos varios.

Uso del Préstamo

Lucila solicita el crédito para comprar mas medicamentos y cumplir con su demanda, también necesita comprar una puerta corrediza para dar mejor seguridad a su local.

Información Personal

Lucila tiene 39 años 1 hijo de 12 años. Su esposo trabaja como vendedor de calzado y se apoyan en la atención de su negocio. Tiene anhelo de seguir construyendo su vivienda e indican que para esto tienen que incrementar más su negocio de Farmacia. Y así poder dar mayor seguridad en su hogar.

loans.use: Invest in medications

loans.name: Laito Facela

texts.pt:
Iaito is single but lives with a woman with whom he has 4 children. He works for the Police Authority of the Republic of Mozambique. His children attend school. He has not been able to purchase electric appliances for his home on his salary, as he is the only one who works outside the home. His wife is a homemaker.

Translated from Portuguese by Leo Duran, Kiva Volunteer.

laito e solteiro mas vive com uma mulher com quem tem 4 filhos. Ele e trabalhador do Comando da Policia da Republica de Mocambique. Os seus filhos estao a estudar.Todavia, so com o salario que ele ganha nao consegue comprar electrodomesticos para a sua casa, pois que ele e o unico a trabalhr fora de casa. A sua esposa e apenas domestica.

loans.use: Iaito would like to use the funds to purchase electric appliances for this home

loans.name: Touch

texts.en:
Mrs. Touch S. married in 1993. She has one son and one daughter. She learned to weave silk from her mother in 1990 and began her silk production in the same year. She did not finish primary school. Her husband is a construction contractor. He started his construction business in 1997. Their two children are being sent to attend school in the village and they hope that their children can continue studying in higher education in the future.

Mrs. S. is requesting a loan from MAXIMA for the second time, this time in the amount of US$ 350. She will use this loan to purchase silk materials, sewing thread, and pay fees for selecting and preparing silk on the looms.

loans.use: Purchasing silk materials, sewing thread, and fees for selecting and preparing silk on the looms

loans.name: Mary's Group

texts.en:
Mary N. makes juice in Kasubi, Uganda. With a loan, Mary wants to buy another refrigerator where she can store the juice for sale.

Background on BRAC and BRAC Uganda

BRAC (Building Resources Across Communities) is a development organization that began operations in Bangladesh as a small-scale relief and rehabilitation project in 1972 to help the country overcome the devastation and trauma of the liberation war and focused on resettling refugees returning from India. Today, BRAC has emerged as an independent, virtually self-financed paradigm in sustainable human development. It is one of the largest Southern development organizations employing over 100,000 people, 61% of which are women, and working with the twin objectives of poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor. Diagnosing poverty in human terms and recognizing its multifaceted nature, BRAC approaches poverty alleviation with a holistic approach.

The successes of BRAC in the international development arena have stimulated a series of discussions, both with African delegations, who have visited BRAC programs, and with donors who work in Asia and Africa. Both the African countries and the donors have encouraged BRAC to join the development campaign in Africa to achieve the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) and more recently to join the campaign of “ending poverty”, which is an area where Africa represents the greatest global challenge.

In Uganda, BRAC registered as a Non Government Organization (NGO) in January 2006 to undertake programs in Education, Health, Water & Sanitation, Agriculture & Livestock and Microfinance. The Microfinance and Education are the pioneer programs launched in Uganda and, as of July 2007, had served 21,273 borrowers and enrolled 1,155 adolescents in its education program.

loans.use: To buy a refrigerator

loans.name: Gudilah

texts.en:
Mambo from Mwanza, Tanzania! This is 27-year-old Gudilah M.. She is married with two children, aged 4 and 8. In 1996 Gudilah established a shop selling general items, and now requires a loan of $450 in order to purchase additional stock in bulk. She thanks you for your support.

About SELFINA
SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed not-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital SELFINA buys equipment from said client, extending a loan to her, then leasing back the same equipment – a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock for her general store.

loans.name: Nhóm Chị Phương - Tiên Trà - Trung Nghĩa Group

texts.vi:
Mrs. Phương, 37 years old, is a village market trader. She also raises chickens and tends a grocery stand. Her husband passes away so she must work harder to support three school age children. She would use funds of the loan to buy goods, same as Mrs. Tường. Mrs. Minh would use funds of the loan to invest in poultry, same as Mrs. Trai.

Translated from Vietnamese by ngungo, Kiva volunteer.


Chị Phương, 37 tuổi đi chợ, chăn nuôi gà và bán hàng đồ khô, tạp hoá. Chồng chị đã mất nên chị rất vất vả. Chị phải nuôi ba con còn nhỏ. Các cháu đều đang đi học. Chị vay vốn để mua hàng khô bán. Chị Minh vay vốn để chăn nuôi. Chị Tường vay vốn để đi chợ. Chi Trai vay vốn để chăn nuôi.

loans.use: Buy goods

loans.name: Abed

texts.en: Abed is a 24-year-old man living in Tripoli, Northern Lebanon. He owns a used clothing store. This is the third time he is applying for a loan at A. Majmoua. He wants to buy merchandise for the coming season.

loans.use: to buy merchandise

loans.name: Neema's Imani Group

texts.en:
Neema is 29 years old and is married with 2 children, ages 8 and 3 years old. Neema is a clothes seller; she started in 2005. Every day she works from 8am to 10pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $140 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more clothes for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses dealing in fish sales, food vending and clothes sales.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for her business.

loans.name: Alassane

texts.fr:
This young stockbreeder has invested in the pasteurisation of milk in order to participate in the development of his country. He wants to buy a large quantity of milk regularly in response to the demand of his clientele for buttermilk or fresh milk packaged in bags of 1/4 liter each. This loan will permit him to reinforce his position in the burgeoning milk industry which contributes to the struggle against malnutrition in this part of Senegal.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

Ce jeune éleveur s'est investi dans la pasteurisation du lait pour participer au développement de son pays. Il veut acheter réguliérement de grande quantité de lait pour répondre à la demande de sa clientéle en lait caillé ou lait frais mis en sachet dans des emballages de 1/4l. Ce crédit lui permettra donc de conforter sa position de PME émergente dans la filiére lait qui contribue à la lutte contre la malnutrition dans cette partie du Sénégal.

loans.use: purchase of milk for processing

loans.name: Sabina

texts.es:
Ms. Sabina lives in the community of Chambi Chocaque in the Yunguyo province and district. She is a member of the Nueva Vida (New Life) Communal Bank and is 48. She studied up to the sixth grade and has four children. She also cares for a niece who was orphaned. Her husband is disabled due to injuries he received in a traffic accident many years ago.

Currently, she works making women's clothing, such as various kinds of skirts and wool undergarments. She sells her products from a stand in the 15 de Agosto Market in Yunguyo. She decided to start this business because of her oldest son, who was studying at the Altiplano-Puno National University and couldn't afford what he needed for school, such as materials, etc. In light of this, one of his school friends suggested that he learn to sew shawls by machine. He told he mother about the idea and she immediately decided to buy a second-hand sewing machine. Next, they both learned to make the shawls.

At the time, Ms. Sabina only had two thirds of the money she needed to buy the sewing machine, so she went to Ms. Toribia Pilco to ask about getting a loan from the microfinance institute Manuela [Ramos]. She quickly decided to join her community's Communal Bank. That's how she was granted her first loan of S/. 300.00 nuevo soles [local currency], in order to pay for the sewing machine. She is now seeking a loan of S/. 500.00 in order to purchase different colored wools. She will repay the loan in four months.

Ms. Sabina is very happy at present, as all of her children have learned to sew. This joint family effort has helped the family increase its income. In the future, Ms. Sabina would like to buy more sewing machines and increase her business, becoming a successful businesswoman in the Yunguyo province.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Chegezy, Kiva volunteer.

Doña Sabina vive en la comunidad de Chambi Chocaque del distrito y provincia de Yunguyo y pertenece al Banco Comunal Nueva Vida, tiene 48 años de edad, estudió hasta sexto de primaria y es madre de 4 hijos y es responsable de una sobrina huerfanita. Su esposo es inválido por el accidente de tránsito que sufrió hace mucho tiempo.

Ella actualmente se dedica en la confección de prendas de vestir exclusivo para damas como: enaguas, centros, combinaciones de lana en su mayoría. La venta lo realiza en el puesto que tiene en el mercado 15 de agosto de Yunguyo. Esta actividad fue motivada por su hijo mayor quién estudiaba, en ese entonces, en la Universidad Nacional del Altiplano-Puno, en donde no tenía dinero para sus separatas, cuotas en su salón, frente a ello uno de sus compañeros lo animó a tejer chalinas a máquina. Luego todo ello le contó a su madre y ella inmediatamente decidió comprar una máquina de tejer (de segunda), y también lograron aprender a tejer las prendas.

En ese entonces, para el pago de la máquina le faltaba una tercera parte del capital, por ello ha recurrido ante la señora Toribia Pilco para que explique sobre cómo acceder al crédito de Manuela, inmediatamente decidió constituir el Banco Comunal en su comunidad. Así accedió al primer préstamo de S/. 300.00 nuevos soles para cancelar la máquina de tejer. Con este préstamo de S/. 500.00 comprará lanas de diferentes colores. Este crédito lo pagará en 4 meses.

Ahora ella se encuentra contenta porque todos sus hijos aprendieron a confeccionar y mejoró sus ingresos, gracias al esfuerzo conjunto de su familia. Su perspectiva a futuro es implementar con más maquinas de tejer y ser empresaria exitosa en la provincia de Yunguyo.

loans.use: Wholesale purchase of wool.

loans.name: Pak

texts.en:
Pak P., 28, runs a small construction business. He employs a few workers for his building operations and earns around US$10 per day. His wife, pictured in the photograph, is a farmer and sells crops in the market, earning around US$2 per day. The couple has two children, both of them very young, and the family lives in the Beong Chum Village, Siem Reap Province. Currently, P. needs a loan of US$1,000 to be able to expand his business. Specifically, he will use the borrowed money to purchase a cement-mixing machine. The loan will thus allow him to offer additional construction services and thereby increase his income.

About Hattha Kaksekar Limited (HKL): Hattha Kaksekar Limited (HKL) is one of Cambodia's largest and most successful microfinance institutions (MFIs). It is committed to helping its clients achieve their business goals by providing sound financial services, and thereby hopes to contribute to the social and economic development of Cambodia. HKL specifically targets women and poor families in order to help them achieve increased financial security and quality of life, by offering various credit programs and encouraging savings. In accordance with its mission and its commitment to operational and financial sustainability, HKL contributes part of its net profits every year to support social development in education and healthcare.

loans.use: Purchase of a cement-mixing machine

loans.name: Chhon

texts.en:
Mr. Chhon Y. is a pig breeder in Thnorl Roling Village in Kampong Chhnang Province. As a retired soldier, he receives a small salary to support his family. His wife, Mrs. Net Yoeun, is a Khmer noodle seller. Mr. Chhon Y. is 56 years old and has four children. One child sells Khmer noodles with his mother, and the other children attend school.

Although this family has multiple businesses, they still do not have enough money to build a new house. Thus, Mr. Y. is requesting a loan to add to his savings to build a new house for his family. Previously, Mr. Y. obtained a loan to start his pig breeding business. He has fully repaid the loan.

loans.use: Add to savings to build a new house for the family

loans.name: Jesca

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 34-year-old Jesca S. from Mwanza. Married with three children between the ages of three and ten, Jesca has been running a poultry-selling business since 2000. Working ten hours a day, six days per week and assisted by one employee, she currently earns about $200 monthly from her business. Jesca is requesting a loan of $1050 to buy 500 chickens, and in the future plans to buy even more. She thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility.

loans.use: To buy 500 chickens

loans.name: Rosalith

texts.es:
La señora Rosalith pertenece al Banco Comunal “Virgen del Rosario”, vive en la región San Martín, provincia y distrito de Bellavista. Se dedica a la venta de coco rallado, listo para la utilización en dulces y otros usos. Abastece a Lima y otras regiones, lugares de donde le solicitan su producto por la calidad de ellos, además complementa su negocio con la venta de bebidas gasificadas en su casa.

Con este crédito de S/.2,500, el cual será pagado en 6 meses, comprará cocos en grandes cantidades para luego pelar y rallar para poder atender los pedidos que le hacen, también comprará agua mineral y gaseosas de diversas marcas, tamaños y sabores para atender las exigencias de sus clientes.

La señora Rosalith tiene 48 años de edad, vive con su esposo quien la apoya en esta actividad, ambos trabajan duro para salir adelante. Es una mujer emprendedora que desea más adelante implementar su venta de gaseosas con abarrotes, quiere contar con una bodega en su propia casa.
texts.en:
Rosalith is a member of the "Virgen del Rosario" [Virgin of the Rosary] Community Bank. She lives in San Martin region, Bellavista province and district. She sells grated coconut, which can be used for making sweets and other uses. She sells coconut in Lima and other areas from which she receives orders for her products, which are known for their quality. In addition, she complements her coconut business by selling soft drinks out of her home. With this loan of 2,500 soles [about US $ 825] -- which will be paid back in six months -- Rosalith plans to purchase large quantities of coconuts, which will then be peeled and grated to fill the orders she receives from her clients. She also will buy mineral water and soft drinks (various brands, sizes and flavors) to meet the demands of her customers. Rosalith is 48 years old and lives with her husband, who supports her in her business activity. They both work hard to get ahead. Rosalith is an enterprising woman who, in the future, would like to establish a convenience store where she sells not only soft drinks but also other products. She would like to own and operate a small grocery store out of her house.

Translated from Spanish by Todd M. Anderson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of large quantities of coconuts, as well as mineral water and soft drinks

loans.name: Teresa Petrona

texts.es:
La Sra. Teresa Petrona trabaja desD. los cinco años D. edad, en un principio se dedicaba a la
venta D. verduras en un mercado D. la zona Sur, una zona residencial D. la ciudad D. La Paz, Bolivia, DesD. hace 2 años que trabaja en el rubro D. la venta D. alimenbtos en un comedor popular D. la ciudad y es D. esa manera que genera ingresos para su alimentacion diaria, felizmente, como refiere, cuenta con el apoyo D. su esposo quien es chofer asalariado y entre los dos tratan D. sacar adelante a sus hijos.
texts.en:
Mrs Teresa Petrona has been working since the age of five. At first, she maD. her living selling vegetables in a market in "la zona Sur”, a residential area of south La Paz, in Bolivia. For 2 years now, she has been selling food in one of the city’s well-known restaurants and in this way she has been earning enough money to happily feed her family on a daily basis. However, she also relies on the support from her husband who earns his salary as a chauffeur. Together they are trying to proviD. their children with a better future.

Translated from Spanish by Sara Roden-Scott, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy consumables

loans.name: Hean

texts.en: Hean H. L., 59, is a widow who lives with eight of her children in Kampong Cham province. She uses her mill to take off rice husk for a profit. On average, she earns around US$ 6 a day and is also supported by six of her children. She would like to take out a loan of US$ 1200 to add to her stock of rice. This will increase the amount of rice she can husk each day.

loans.use: To purchase rice to husk for sale

loans.name: Jovita Elizabeth

texts.en:
Jovita Elizabeth R. S. is forty-one years old, married and has three children.  Her husband works as a mechanic and Jovita supports her family with her beauty salon.  Jovita has worked with the Mujeres Emprendedoras, or Women Entrepreneurs, bank for eight years.  As her business has grown Jovita has increased her loan amounts from 300 Nuevo Soles to over 2,000.

Jovita is currently requesting 2,200 Nuevo Soles to augment her hair salon business.  Jovita plans to purchase lingerie to offer to her customers while she is cutting their hair.  She will also continue to purchase hair dressing liquids and materials with her loan.  Jovita plans to repay the loan in six months.

loans.use: To purchase lingerie to offer to her customers while she is cutting their hair

loans.name: Martha

texts.es: La Sra. S. M. es pequeña productora de arroz, el marido tiene problemas de invalidez por lo que la señora solicitante tiene que atender la produccion de arroz y el hogar, todos sus hijos son mayores y no habitan en la casa.  Diariamente asiste a sus areas de produccion; con la presente solicitud pretende incorporarse como socia de un trillo arrocero que le permitira obtener mayores ingresos de su produccion.
texts.en:
Mrs. S. M. is a small producer of rice. Her husband suffers from mobility problems, and she is requesting this loan because she must see to both the rice production and the home. All her children are now grown and living on their own. She tends to her areas of production on a daily basis; with the current loan, she would like to become part of a group of owners of a rice thresher. This would allow her to generate better income from her production.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To contribute toward construction of a rice thresher.

loans.name: Maryle

texts.en:
Maryle A. grows rice to earn a living. Her life is on the farm. Her parents taught her everything she knows about farming, such as how to plant rice and other crops. They hoped that when the time came for her to have her own family, she would know how to support her children. Her husband Marlino A. is a very experienced farmer. Together, they work hard for their family's future. Eleven years ago, that they started their rice farm business. They reserve a portion of the harvest for their family and they sell the remainder to rice traders in town.

Maryle is asking for a loan of Php 10,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to buy fertilizers and seeds. She believes that the loan will help to give her a better return on her business investment. She hopes that increased income will hep to improve their living conditions.

Joining the CEVI credit program gave Maryle access to credit assistance, training, and insurance coverage.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and seeds

loans.name: Okhunbobo

texts.en:
D. Okhunbobo is the happily married father of two children. He leases eight hectares of land, all of which are planted with vegetables, as there is generally adequate irrigation all year round in the area. Thus, over the course of a year, the land can be planted on a rotational basis with potato, tomato, cucumber, wheat, and barley. Besides these, he has many fruit trees on his land. This rotational planting process preserves the richness of the land. Of course, it is also dependent on the weather.

For cultivating land this size, Okhunbobo requires additional funds to increase his expected yield. Last season, Okhunbobo faced considerable difficulties in terms of supplying his land with sufficient water. He has applied to IMON International for a loan in order to ensure a good yield of fruits and vegetables. This is Okhunbobo’s first loan and he is sure that his successful efforts will increase his income and improve his family’s welfare.

More about Tajikistan

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes being a key post along the Silk Road and being the location of the end of the rule of Alexander the Great. It is also known for its famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, such as Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi, and many others. The country, filled with epic mountain passes, is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, and boasts a civilization that dates back to the fourth millennium BC. Even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93 percent of the country is mountainous and only 7 percent of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

More about IMON International

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit www.imon.tj.

loans.use: Purchasing of seeds and fertilizer.

loans.name: Viola

texts.en:
Viola M. is 25-years old, married, and has two children in school.  She is in the business of selling beer, and is requesting a loan to open a bar. She will also use the loan to pay her children's school fees.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To open a bar

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Elizabeth is 49 years old and married with 5 children. She sells sachet water (packaged/bottled "pure" water) in wholesale and retail to her customers. She hopes for the loan amount of $350 to purchase more sachet water to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sachet water to sell

loans.name: Ly

texts.en: Ly D., 61, pictured here with her daughter, is a widow who lives with one of her children in the Kampong Cham province. She grows rice and sells grocery items from her home. On average, she earns a combined income of about US$2 per day. She is also supported by her daughter, who sells fish in the market. Ly is asking for a loan to purchase more fish for her daughter to sell at the market.

loans.use: To purchase fish to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more seed for his farm

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: growing sweet potatoes and yams

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is 45 years old, divorced, and the mother of seven children. One is schooling, one is breastfeeding and the rest are working. Elizabeth is a petty trader. She sells onions, tubers of yam, tomatoes, peppers, etc., on a table in the local market of Sefwi in the western region of Ghana where she lives.

She says that she has endeavored to upgrade her business to expected levels but, for some time now, she has been facing challenges in her business due to inadequate funds. She requests the loan to enable her buy an increased stock of tomatoes, tubers of yam, onions and peppers to scale up her business. She hopes to increase her savings to support the children’s education and to give them a future and hope.

loans.use: To buy an increased stock of yam, onions, tomatoes, peppers and other spices

loans.name: Annie

texts.en:
Annie R. manages a small sari-sari store business. She is 56 years old and has six children. She started her business in 2004. The income that she earns from selling different kinds of goods is a big help, especially in paying for books and school fees. 

Now, she wants her business to grow even more. By buying additional merchandise for her store, she thinks that she will be able to attract more customers and to increase her income as well.

Community Economic Ventures is helping her to get a loan to support her business. They also provide her with training and an insurance coverage package.

loans.use: To purchase assorted groceries for retail.

loans.name: Ngin

texts.en:
T. is a 50-year-old single mother and a resident of Siem Reap Province. She was married, but her husband died of senility many years ago. She has seven children, two of whom live with her and depend on her income. The other five are married and have started new homes. Currently, the income she earns comes from farming. She grows rice and vegetables, which she sells to buyers in bulk every two or three months when the plants mature. 

T. will use her loan to better supply her farm by buying more fertilizer and seeds for her growing facilities. She appears in the photo with her daughter at her farm.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizer and seeds

loans.name: Florenda

texts.en:
Florenda has been able to send her only child to school through to college. However, her daughter wasn't able to graduate as she got married instead. Florenda earned the money to educate her daughter from her business producing and selling sweet delicacies. Now, since her dream of a better life for her child has not been realized, she wants to stabilize her business and make it grow in order to help her daughter. Florenda joined Kiva partner, ASHI, in the last week of July, and requested a loan for use as additional capital. 

Florenda also wants to start a charcoal business and a vegetable-selling business. One day, with the help of loans from ASHI, Florenda hopes to be able to produce a greater variety of sweet delicacies and sell them in different towns nearby. She would also like to purchase a motorcycle so that she can accept orders and deliver her products. Florenda also wants to build a canteen in one of the schools where she sells her products every day. Her ultimate dream of building a concrete house for her family will be in reach when she reaps the profits her businesses make.

loans.use: To finance her charcoal business, and sweet delicacy (food) business

loans.name: Kotognongontala Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Kotognongontala sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne  d’âge de 36 ans et 2  enfants. Avec leur mari et enfants elles vivent  dans des familles traditionnelles et  résident dans la ville de Fana, quartier Banankabougou, Région  de  Koulikoro  République du Mali. 
Ces femmes se sont  connues par des liens de parenté, d’amitié et font le commerce d’articles divers et la restauration. 
Elles sont à leur cinquième prêt solidaire et tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Elles veulent acheter du riz, des condiments alimentaires pour la restauration et  des tissus auprès des grossistes des différents marchés de Bamako (capitale de la république du Mali).
Elles font leurs ventes dans  le marché de Fana, surtout les jours de foires où elles réalisent beaucoup de ventes avec l’arrivée des forains et des routiers. 
Elles comptent obtenir chacune, mensuellement  10.000 FCFA de bénéfice qui sera réutilisé dans les activités et servira à s’occuper pour d’autres besoins.
texts.en:
The members of the group Kotognongontala are married women who average 36 years of age and 2 children. With their husband and children, they live in traditional families and reside in the city of Fana, Banankabougou district, Koulikoro region, in the Republic of Mali. These women know one another through ties of kinship and friendship, and they do commerce in various goods and in food service. They are on their fifth solidarity loan, and the preceding ones have all been properly repaid. They want to buy rice, some condiments for food catering, and some cloth from wholesale vendors at different markets of Bamako (capital of Mali). Sales are made at the Fana market, especially on fair days, when many sales are made with the arrival of fair vendors and truck drivers. The group members each plan on having a monthly profit of 10,000 francs CFA that will be reused in business and will serve to take care of other needs.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various goods

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace is 37 years old. She is married and has given birth to two children, both of whom are in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a town called Wiawso in the Western Region of Ghana. Wiawso is a commercial and farming town. 

Grace is a food vendor. She cooks and sells rice with stew. She sells from a tabletop by the roadside in her community. Grace buys bags of rice and other ingredients from nearby towns. She has been in business for more than 15 years and wants a loan to buy goods in bulk to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy bags of rice

loans.name: Irene

texts.es:
Irene tiene 63 años, es una mujer que a lo largo de su vida ha trabajado mucho para salir adelante, vive en su casa propia y lo que más desea es tener una vejez tranquila. Su tienda de abarrotes es una de las más concurridas de su barrio, el gran carisma que posee y la amabilidad en su trato han hecho que sea la preferida por sus vecinos, quienes no dudan en hacer sus compras desde muy temprano, ya que saben que es la primera en abrir.

Lo que más le gusta de su trabajo es conversar con sus vecinos sobre las cosas que suceden en su barrio, lleva 20 años en esta actividad y considera que lo más difícil es tener que permanecer todo el día dentro de su tienda, ya que tiene que atender de corrido si no quiere que sus ventas bajen. Para el futuro espera que su negocio crezca y se convierta en el almacén principal de su barrio.

Este el quinto préstamo de Irene con MFP, sabe que si lo paga a tiempo podrá acceder a otro con mayor tranquilidad y sin traerle complicaciones a su banco comunal, donde es muy querida por el resto de sus compañeras. Con los dos mil nuevos soles solicitados comprará más provisiones para su tienda de abarrotes y así incrementará su stock de productos.
texts.en:
Irene is 63 years old. She is a woman who has worked hard throughout her life in order to get ahead. Irene lives in her own home and hopes to have a peaceful retirement. She manages a grocery store in one of the more crowded areas of her neighborhood. Her charismatic and kind personality makes her popular amongst her neighbors, who do not hesitate to shop early because her store is one of the first to open.

What she enjoys most about her job is talking with her customers about events that occur in the neighborhood. Irene has been in business for 20 years and says the most difficult part is spending all day inside her store, yet she knows that she has to continually attend to customers if she does not want sales to decline. In the future, she hopes to increase her business so that it becomes the largest store in the neighborhood.

This is Irene’s fifth loan with MFP. She knows she has to make her payments on time in order to access more loans without creating complications for her Communal Bank. Irene is revered by the other members of her group. With a loan of 2000 soles, she plans to buy more provisions for her grocery store and increase her inventory of products.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase her inventory of merchandise

loans.name: Antoinette

texts.fr: A. Antoinette est née en 1980 à Sahouè au Sud du Bénin. Mariée à AYETCHE Paulin, un transitaire, Antoinette est mère de deux enfants dont un est scolarisé. Le couple vit ensemble avec leurs enfants à Gbodjè à Porto-Novo, ça fait six mois de cela. Antoinette a arrêté l'école au cours primaire. Afin d'aider son mari Paulin dans les charges de la famille, Antoinette vend depuis cinq ans déjà, des sacs de maïs et de riz à son domicile. Antoinette mène également comme activité secondaire, la vente de tissus par le système de distribution. C'est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin que Antoinette s'approvisionne. Antoinette a déjà bénéficié de deux crédits de ALIDé, crédits qui ont été bien remboursés. Antoinette sollicite un troisième crédit de ALIDé pour augmenter son fonds de roulement et accroître la taille de son activité.
texts.en:
Antoinette A. was born in 1980 in Sahouè in the south of Bénin. She is married to Paulin AYETCHE, a clearing agent. Antoinette is the mother of two children, one is attending school. For the last six months, the couple has been living with their children in Gbodjè in Porto-Novo. Antoinette stopped her education in elementary school. For 5 years already, she has been helping her husband with the family' s expenses. She has been selling bags of corn and rice from her home. Antoinette also has a secondary activity where she sells fabric through the distribution system.

Antoinette stocks up in Dantokpa, the international market of Bénin. Antoinette has already received two loans from ALIDé, those have been fully reimbursed. Antoinette is requesting a third loan from ALIDé to increase her working capital and increase the size of her business.


Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of bags of corn and rice, and bolts of fabric.

loans.name: Mónica Luz

texts.es:
Mónica es una madre de familia de 20 años de edad que vive junto a su esposo y su hijo de año y medio de edad en casa de sus padres, ubicada en Puerto Malabrigo, distrito de Rázuri, provincia de Ascope, en la región La Libertad, ubicada a 3 horas y media de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Desde hace 10 meses de dedica a la venta de ceviche en una esquina cercana a la playa. Anteriormente sólo vendía este plato los días domingo durante la temporada de verano. Pero ahora que tiene un hijo y que junto a su esposo desean terminar de establecerse como familia se está dedicando a vender su producto de lunes a viernes.

El pescado es comprado por su madre en el terminal pesquero de la ciudad de Trujillo. Mónica prepara los platos y los ofrece hasta el mediodía, por la tarde vende diversos dulces en el mismo lugar (mazamorra, arroz con leche, dulces típicos del país). Su buena sazón y su trato amable han hecho que su negocio sea muy visitado por sus habituales clientes.

Su esposo trabaja eventualmente como obrero de construcción y con estos ingresos están sacando adelante a su joven familia. Debido a la constante demanda de sus clientes Mónica desea ampliar su negocio por lo que está solicitando por primera vez  Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 1000 nuevos soles para utlizarlos en la compra de una carreta donde pueda ofrecer sus productos con mayor comodidad.

Su más grande anhelo es poder instalar una cebichería y construir su casa propia, ella es una mujer trabajadora y muy resposnable.
texts.en:
Mónica is a 20 year old mother who lives with her husband and one and a half year old son in her parent’s home, located in Puerto Malabrigo, Rázuri district, Ascope province, La Libertad region, located 3.5 hours from Chiclayo city. For 10 months she has been selling ceviche on a corner near the beach. Previously she only sold this dish on Sundays during the summer. But now she has a son and along with her husband they wish to establish themselves as a family so she is selling this product Monday through Friday. The fish is purchased by her mother in the fish market in Trujillo city. Mónica prepares the dishes and sells them until midday, in the afternoon she sells a variety of sweets in the same place (pudding, rice pudding and typical sweets of her country). Her good seasoning and customer services have made her business frequently visited by her steady customers. Her husband works as a construction worker and with these incomes they are making ends meet for their young family. Due to the constant demand of her customers Mónica wishes to expand her business so she is seeking her first loan for 1000 nuevos soles with Edpyme Alternativa to be used to buy a cart where she can offer her products with greater comfort. Her greatest wish is to be able to open a ceviche café and build her own home. She is a very hard working and responsible woman.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy a mobile cart to sell ceviche

location.town: Puerto Malabrigo - Rázuri - Ascope - La Libertad

loans.name: Teresa De Jesús

texts.es: Teresa de Jesús G. de 48 años de edad, reside en Colón en el departamento de la Libertad, vive junto a sus dos hijos menores de edad, los cuales depende únicamente de ella. Teresa posee una venta de ropa en las afueras del mercado de Santa Tecla y en el vende ropa para niños y adultos de ambos sexos. Ella solicita un préstamo con el fin de poder comprar  más ropa, ya que desea aprovechar la temporada navideña, esperando aumentar sus ventas y poder brindarles todo lo mejor a sus hijos, sobre todo en esta temporada de fin de año.
texts.en:
Teresa de Jesús G., 48, lives in Colón in the Libertad department. She lives with her two minor children. They are dependent solely upon her. Teresa has a business selling clothes on the outskirts of the Santa Tecla Market. She sells clothing for children and adults of both sexes. She is asking for a loan to be able to buy more clothes. She wants to take advantage of the Christmas season. She is hoping to increase her sales to be able to give her children the best, especially in this season at the end of the year.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy more clothes

loans.name: Anna's Group

texts.en: Anna I. is 49 years old and married with one child. Her daughter is 28 years old, married, and takes care of 4 orphans. Anna has a retail shop and animal husbandry businesses. The shop was her first business and in order to improve the quality of life for her family. She started the animal husbandry business, although during the dry season, the food for the animals is scarce and there is high competition with her shop. In Anna’s shop, she sells sugar, salt, maize flour, etc,; with the cows, she sells milk for a daily income. She is able to make 40,000 UGX a week in profit and in the future she would like to change her retail shop into a hardware shop and to expand her animal husbandry business. She also hopes to build another residential house that is more presentable. Anna needs a loan to be able to improve the corral for the animals by buying materials to construct it. She is such a hard working lady.

loans.use: To buy construction materials for improving her corral at home.

loans.name: Loida

texts.en: Loida C. is from the "barangay" (village) of Maular, a village located in Aloran, Misamis Occidental. She is 39 years old, is married, and has two school-aged children. Loida owns and operates a sari-sari (general) store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Loida joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. Loida is requesting a new loan of 3,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her 6th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Wilfredo

texts.es:
Nuestro socio es el señor WILFREDO, ella pertenece al banco comunal “MUJERES UNIDAS”, el socio vive en el departamento del Cusco.

Nuestro socio tiene 30 años de edad es conviviente y tiene 1 hijo 9 años de edad, el socio trabaja hace 5 años en transporte, el tiene su carrito y lo puso  atrabajar en transporte urbano cubriendo la ruta de Cusco hacia la provincia de Anta- Iscuchaka, nuestro socio maneja todos los días de la ciudad del Cusco a Iscuchaka un promedio de 1 hora ida y vuelta llevando y trayendo pasajeros, nuestro socio solicita el préstamo para poder hacerle un mantenimiento general a su auto y así tenerlo en optimas condiciones para su normal desempeño.

El socio  agradece y expresa su satisfacción de poder seguir creciendo con su negocio propio y se compromete a cumplir con el pago  de su deuda en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
Our partner is Mr. Wilfredo, who belongs to the "Mujeres Unidas" communal bank. The partner lives in the Cusco department. Our partner is 30 years old and lives with his partner and 9 year old son. The partner has been working in transport for 5 years, he has his own car and has been servicing the urban transport route from Cusco to the Anta Iscuchaka province. Our partner drives his car every day from Cusco to Iscuchaka for an average of an hour round trip, transporting passengers. Our partner is requesting a loan for the general maintenance on his car, so that it can perform in optimal condition. The partner is grateful and expresses his satisfaction to be able to keep growing with his own business and is committed to fulfill the payment of his debt in the established period.

Translated from Spanish by Esteban Riojas, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Car maintenance

loans.name: Luz

texts.es:
Luz, de 45 años, vive en su casa propia al lado de sus padres y sus 3 hijos; Vladimir (24), José (21) y Jair (19).
Desde hace 3 años se inició en la venta de productos de belleza, esta actividad la realiza junto a una amiga, y como tiene poder de convencimiento puede obtener buenas ganancias debido a sus altas ventas. A luz le gusta recomendar los tonos de maquillaje a sus asiduas clientes, además es una labor tranquila, pues ofrece los productos mediante un catalogo y posteriormente reparte los pedidos y hace la cobranzas. Por tal motivo, piensa continuar en el negocio, ya que no tiene mayores dificultades al hacerlo y le permite no descuidar la crianza de sus hijos. 
Y como es una mujer muy emprendedora y quiere salir adelante, tiene planeado para el futuro instalar una tienda en su vivienda y ahí mismo ofrecer sus productos de belleza.

Este es el 8vo préstamo que tiene con MFP y promete ser muy responsable en el pago de cada una de sus cuotas, ya que no quiere quedar mal con los integrantes de su grupo. Luz tiene pensado invertir el dinero que solicita en la compra de nuevos productos de belleza, para así tener en stock y ofrecerlos a un mayor precio.
texts.en:
Luz is 45 years old. She lives in her own home with her parents and her three children: Vladimir (24), Jose (21) and Jair (19). Three years ago she started selling beauty products. She does this activity together with a friend. Since she has the power of persuasion, she is able to make good profits due to her high sales. Luz likes to recommend the makeup tones to her regular customers. In addition, it is a calm business. She offers the products through a catalog and later delivers the orders and collects the money. For this reason, she is planning to continue in this business, since she has had no major problems with it and it allows her to raise her children. Since she is a very hard working woman and wants to get ahead, she plans to have a store in her house in the future and offer her beauty products. This is the 8th loan that she has had with MFP and she promises to be very responsible with making her payments since she wants to do right by the other members of the group. Luz is planning on investing the money she is asking for in the purchase of new beauty products in order to have them in stock and offer them at a higher price.

Translated from Spanish by Ellen Donohue, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase merchandise

loans.name: Levey

texts.en:
Levey G. is from the village of Banquero. She is 38 years-old and is married and has three school-aged children. Levey owns and operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Levey has been engaged in her business for over one year and earns approximately 1,000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Levey joined Kiva partner ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Levey is requesting a first loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and North-eastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishers and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items.

loans.name: Tes

texts.en:
Tes N. sells fresh fish that she either gets from her husband’s fishing or buys from other fishermen. In order to earn extra proceeds, Tes N. is looking for assistance via Kiva’s field partner, HKL. She will be using her loan to buy a plot of land in a good location for farming, which she will then rent to other farmers for a fee. 

Tes N. is married with six children. She has established a medium-sized house where she lives with other family members in Kompong Tom province. (Mrs. Tes N. was not available for taking a photo, so her husband is pictured instead.)

loans.use: To buy a plot of farm land

loans.name: Mira's Group

texts.en: Mira J. is a widow who has been managing her household on her own. She has a son, who is 23. The son is a member of a farm association. She and her son make their living by raising cattle. Three years ago, Mira bought some sheep and started breeding. In spite of all the difficulties, she was able to save $340 and invest in purchasing cattle. Now her monthly income constitutes around $135. Mira has applied for this loan as she hopes to buy a cow to feed and subsequently sell its milk. This coming fall, she plans to marry her son. It is refreshing to see how people of a relatively old age show this much perseverance and genuine desire to achieve success in their businesses. They are like the runner who has run all the way and, when everybody expects he will fall down from exhaustion and fatigue, suddenly looks ahead and with a smile begins to pick up his pace. Mira is the leader of this group. Mira’s partners are: Gulsyina, 51, is a widow. She has two children. To make a living, Gulsyina keeps some cattle. Her children provide a tremendous help looking after the cattle. Gulsyina's monthly income from trading in cattle is around $95. Gulsyina needs a loan to invest in increasing the total population of her livestock. Toktobubu, 48, is married and has two children. Her husband is an electrician. They keep cattle and sell some of their livestock from time to time to meet their needs. Toktobubu needs a loan to invest in purchasing more cattle. Jyldyz, 49, is divorced. She is the mother of three children. All the children help their mother look after the livestock. The eldest son is a farmer; the other two children still go to school. Jyldyz has applied for this loan to increase the total population of her livestock. ====================================== Where Did This Loan Come From? This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3 P's concept: People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To buy a cow

loans.name: Théodora

texts.fr: Née en 1970 à Abomey dans le département du Zou, S. Théodora vit depuis quinze ans à Gbodjè, dans la commune d'Abomey Calavi au Bénin. Théodora est mariée à ANANI Noel, un menuisier, et est mère de trois enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. Théodora vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari. Le couple assure les différentes charges de la famille. Théodora a très peu fréquenté, mais a appris la couture. Théodora exerce cette activité depuis huit ans environs. Parallèlement à cette activité, Théodora vend des articles de mercerie et aussi des bijoux dans son atelier situé à son domicile. Théodora s'approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Théodora  avait une fois bénéficié de crédit auprès de ALIDé, crédit qu'elle a bien remboursé. Dans l'optique de renforcer son activité et d'accroître son chiffre d'affaire, Théodora sollicite un deuxième prêt de ALIDé. Théodora ambitionne plus tard construire un nouveau lieu de vente de ses produits.
texts.en:
Born in 1970 in Abomey in the "département" (administrative district) of Zou, Théodora S. has lived for the past 15 years in Gbodjè in the municipality of Abomey Calavi in Bénin. She is married to Noel ANANI, a carpenter, and is mother to three children who are all at school. Théodora lives with her children and husband. The couple share responsibility for the various family expenses. Théodora went to school very little but learned how to sew. She has been carrying out this activity for around eight years. In parallel, she sells haberdashery products and also jewelry in her workshop, which is in her home. She gets her supplies at Dantokpa, Bénin's international market. Théodora has had one loan from ALIDé which she repaid in full. With a view to strengthening her activity and increasing her turnover, she is applying for a second loan from ALIDé. Her ambition is to build another sales point for her products later on.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of 18 rolls of poplin, 10 dozen zippers, buttons, etc.

loans.name: Ronaldo

texts.es:
Ronaldo R. is from the village of Tambagan, Medina, Misamis Oriental. He is 48 years old. Ronaldo is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Ronaldo owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting & harvesting corn for sale. Ronaldo has been engaged in his business for over 10 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Ronaldo joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ronaldo has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase fertilizers and pesticides. Ronaldo is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the 5th loan taken out by Ronaldo from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement income of the family. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.
texts.en:
Ronaldo R. is from the village of Tambagan, Medina, Misamis Oriental. He is 48 years old. Ronaldo is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Ronaldo owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting & harvesting corn to sell. Ronaldo has had this business for over 10 years and earns about 6,000 PHP a month for these activities. In 2008, Ronaldo joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ronaldo has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase fertilizers and pesticides. Ronaldo is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the 5th loan taken out by Ronaldo from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement income of the family. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

Translated from Spanish by Shelly Hubman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Catedral (Portoviejo) Group

texts.es:
La señora Edith forma parte del Banco Comunal Catedral en la cuidad de Portoviejo capital de la provincia de Manabí en la costa del Ecuador donde existen las mejores playas del Pacífico.
La señora Edith está casada desde hace 12 años tiene tres hijos, a sus 53 años de edad ella se dedica a la venta de comida preparada tiene un restaurant en la parte frontal de su casa, desde hace 9 meses está dedicada a este negocio y cuenta con la ayuda del esposo, A pesar de que el se dedica a lustrar zapatos  en el centro de la ciudad. 

La señora Edith antes de pertenecer a la fundación trabaja como doméstica, una vez que empezó con los créditos de Espoir pudo tener su propio negocio, en las tarde desde las 3 empieza con sus ventas, tiene desde un chuzo (carne asada en palito) hasta un plato más fuerte como arroz menestra y carne asada.

Nuestra socia nos cuenta que con este nuevo crédito podrá comprar una cocina industrial, sillas y mesas para darles mejor atención a sus clientes.
Cuando ella empezó lo hizo con 50 dólares y así pudo comenzar con su restaurant motivada por el esposo no lo pensó dos veces y desde entonces sus ventas marchan bien.  

Visitamos a las socias en día de cierre de ciclo y para conocer más del trabajo de la Fundación Espoir conversamos con la señora Ela es madre de familia casada y tiene 5 hijos mayores tiene 56 años de edad y desde hace 15 años tiene una tienda de víveres ubicada en su propia casa, desde que era muy niña los padres han tenido este negocio en el centro de la ciudad y luego cuando se caso siguió con la tradición, ahora es ella la que mantiene en pie su tienda, el esposo es periodista profesional y en los ratos libres el se encarga de ayudarle, la señora Ela cometa que no tiene día para el descanso asegura que desde las 6 am hasta la media noche tiene abierta trabaja.

Con este nuevo crédito ella invertirá en productos para surtir su tienda tales como; arroz, azúcar, carnes, bebidas como cervezas, gaseosas entre otros, un aproximado de 300 dólares invierte por semana, cuenta la señora Ela que en casa viven sus nietos que son su adoración y ellos les ayudan en las ventas, el sueño de nuestra socia es poder seguir en su tienda y mantener la familia unidad.    

También conversamos con la señorita Karina de 33 años nacida en Portoviejo de profesión Abogada, y además de ejercer ella tiene una tienda en su propia casa y la encargada de atender el negocio es su mamá.

Con el dinero del crédito invertirá en surtir su tienda con productos de primera necesidad y bebidas como cervezas, aguas y colas, desde muy temprano tiene que abrir su negocio y lo está cerrando a las 8 de la noche.
La señorita Karina está conforme con el trabajo que tiene resulta que le deja buenas ganancias, ella cuenta con el apoyo de sus hermanos que son los encargados de hacer los pedidos a los distribuidores un aproximado de 300 dólares por semana invierte para surtir su tienda. El sueño de nuestra socia es poder viajar algunos lugares le encanta conocer otras culturas.
texts.en:
Mrs. Edith is a member of "Banco Comunal Catedral", in the town of Portoviejo, capital of the province of Manabí on the coast of Ecuador where the best beaches on the Pacific Ocean are located. Mrs Edith has been married for 12 years, she has three children, is 53 years old and sells food for a living. She has a restaurant located in front of her house. She has managed this business for 9 months and is being assisted by her husband in spite of his work as a shoe-shiner down-town. Before being a member of the foundation she worked as a maid. Once she started with loans from Espoir she was able to set up her own business. She starts selling at 3 o´clock in the afternoon, she has "chuzo" (grilled meat on a stick) as well as dishes with rice, vegetable stew, and grilled meat. Our partner tells us that with this new loan she will be able to buy an industrial kitchen, chairs and tables to offer more comfort to her customers. She started with 50 dollars and was able to start her restaurant, motivated by the husband, she did not think it twice, and since then her sales have gone well. We visited the partners the last day of the cycle and to know more about the work of Fundación Espoir, we talked to Mrs. Ela, married with 5 grown-up children. She is 56 years old and for 15 years she has had a general store located at her house. Since she was a young girl her parents have had this business down-town, and then when she married she followed the tradition, and now she is the one running the store. Her husband is a professional journalist and in his free time he helps her. Mrs. Ela tells us that she does not have any free time, she works from 6 am till midnight. With this new loan she will invest in products for her store such as rice, sugar, meat, beverages such as beer and sodas among others, she invests approximately 300 dollars per week. Mrs Ela tells us that her grandchildren, whom she adores, live with her and they help sell. It is our partner´s dream to continue with her store and keep the family united. We also talked to Miss Karina who is 33 years old, born in Portoviejo, a lawyer who also has a store at home which her mother looks after. With the money of the loan she will invest in providing her store with essential products and beverages such as beer, water, and coca-colas. She opens her store very early and closes at 8 o´clock in the evening. Miss Karina is satisfied with her work which provides her with good profit, she has the support of her brothers who are in charge of managing the orders to the distributors. Approximately 300 dollars are invested in supplies per week. It is our partner´s dream to travel to other places as she likes to learn about other cultures.

Translated from Spanish by Lene Struck Christensen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase rice, sugar, beverages, meet, etc.

loans.name: Oñondivepa Group

texts.es:
El presente comité se formó gracias a  las ganas que tienen las integrantes para trabajar en grupo y ayudarse de alguna manera para seguir progresando, ella se encuentran en plena actividad dentro del octavo ciclo del programa Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras.
La venta de comestibles es una actividad que realiza muchas mujeres en Paraguay entre ella se encuentra la señora Ramona quien prepara alimentos de diversos tipos para vender.
La venta de sus comestibles lo realiza en forma ambulante recorriendo las zonas concurridas como plazas, mercados y otros, y de esa manera ella vende los productos que prepara cada día.
Su desea es contar con un puesto de venta dentro del mercado para tener un lugar definido para trabajar, pero asegura que en unos meses trabajando mucho logrará su objetivo.
En esta oportunidad solicita el préstamo para la compra de ingredientes como carne, harina de maíz, fideos, panificados y otros.
texts.en:
This group got together thanks to a shared desire to work in a group and help each other to get ahead. Their activities are in full swing in their 8th loan cycle with the "Committee of Enterprising Women" program. Many women in Paraguay have a business selling food, among them is Señora Ramona, who makes a variety of types of food to sell. She is a street vendor who sells the food that she makes in the busiest areas such as plazas, markets and other areas. In this way she sells the products that she makes each day. Her desire is to have a stall inside the market so she can have a defined place to work, but she assures us that with a few months of hard work she will achieve this objective. At this time she is requesting a loan to buy ingredients such as meat, corn meal, noodles, bread and other items.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy ingredients such as: meat, cooking oil, corn meal, noodles and plates to serve the food

loans.name: Esther

texts.es: Esther, de  40 años, es una madre de familia muy emprendedora, vive con su esposo en su casa que es propia. Actualmente se dedica a la  distribución de  aretes, pulseras, collares y demás accesorios para damas. Sus clientes  son los comerciantes de la selva peruana, quienes le hacen pedidos por teléfono y  ella se los envía por  encomiendas de 4  a 6 veces al mes. Está muy satisfecha con éste negocio, ya que le sobra tiempo para dedicarse a sus hijos y a los arreglos de su casa. Además lleva algunos años en este rubro, lo que le ha permitido obtener clientes fijos, y las ganancias superan a las de  su anterior negocio. Por el momento quiere terminar de construir su casa, y después planea  dedicarse íntegramente a ampliar su negocio.Este es su décimo préstamo que tiene con MFP, y sabe que este dinero le será muy beneficioso para aumentar su capital, por ello se compromete en pagar todas sus cuotas oportunamente.Para el futuro tiene planeado  invertir el dinero solicitado en el incremento de su mercadería, al por mayor, para de ese modo cumplir con los pedidos que tiene pendientes.
texts.en:
Ester, 40, is a very enterprising mother who lives with her husband in their own home. She currently sells earrings, bracelets, necklaces and other accessories for women. Her customers are the retailers of the Peruvian jungle. They make orders by phone and she sends them parcels 4 to 6 times per month. She is very satisfied with this business, because she has time left to dedicate to her children and home repairs. She has also been in this area for several years, which has allowed her to obtain loyal clients, and her earnings exceed those of her previous business. Right now, she wants to finish the construction of her home, and after that she plans to work hard on expanding her business. This is her tenth loan with MFP; she knows that it will be very beneficial in increasing her capital, and she promises to repay it on time. She plans to invest the requested loan in increasing her merchandise, buying it wholesale, to fill her pending orders.

Translated from Spanish by Christine Cooper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Merchandise

loans.name: Lucio

texts.en:
Lucio B. F. is a 51-year-old pepper producer and father of nine who lives in the region of Coquital de Los Chiles de San Carlos, located in Northern Costa Rica. Lucio is a dedicated producer and father. He plans to focus his efforts on the planting and harvest of Tabasco peppers. He works in cooperation with his wife to strike a balance between accomplishing the daily tasks associated with agricultural production and the completion of domestic responsibilities. The land they work is their own. 

In addition to his agricultural activity, Lucio works at a local Orange producing factory as a harvesting labourer in order to supplement family income. The money he earns helps pay bills for electricity and to buy food. The rural zone where Lucio and his family live is one of the few places in Costa Rica without running water; the family must pump water from a nearby well as needed. Lucio is working hard towards the sustenance of his family, striving to reap the maximum benefits from his land and his labour. 

Although this is an individual loan, the community in which Lucio and his family live is very close-knit and interdependent. Neighbours help and support one another by sharing experiences and expertise acquired over the years. All individual members of the Coquital community are dedicated to the improvement of living conditions for the region as a whole.

This loan will be used to finance the production of Tabasco peppers. Specifically, the loan will be used to finance the purchase of a variety of seedlings and necessary agricultural nutrients, fertilizers and chemicals in order to ensure a healthy harvest. All labourial and logistical tasks associated with production will be carried out by Lucio with the help of his family members in the region of Coquital de Los Chiles, located in the Northern Region of Costa Rica. Lucio will need roughly one year before his peppers will reach maturity and be ready for harvest. 

Piper and Capiscum Processors Compañía Agrícola Industrial, or, PROPICA is an international buyer and seller of chili pepper and ground pepper products. In cooperation with Fundación Mujer, PROPICA has guaranteed to purchase the agricultural products (the peppers) that are to be produced with the help of this loan. PROPICA acts as a guaranteed client for small agricultural producers in the area of Coquital, thus ensuring that their products will reach market. 

In general, the work day is divided into mornings and afternoons. In the morning, the domestic tasks are carried out such as cooking, cleaning and sending the children to school. Afternoons are generally dedicated to harvest and planting, working the land as needed. Lucio spends some days working as a labourer in the nearby Orange producing factory, but this work is sporadic. Lucio says that he has had difficulty obtaining access to both financial services and technical assistance with respect to farming. This has made it difficult for him and his family to reap the benefits of maximizing their potential productive output on their land. 

The collaboration of Fundación Mujer and PROPICA, represents a unique opportunity to Lucio, his family and community. By offering a source of start-up capital, and a guaranteed client to purchase what is produced, this is a chance to improve family and community standards of living. Above all, Lucio wants to take advantage of the current opportunity that has been presented, he wants to profit from this collaboration and see improvements in his neighbourhood.

loans.use: For the purchase of seeds and nutrients necessary for the production of peppers

loans.name: Urafiki Group

texts.en:
Aloquin N., age 50, is married with 3 children ages 23, 21 and 16 years.  He has operated a cement business for 3 years now.  He works from 8am to 6pm daily and he is able to make a monthly profit of about $336.

This will be  Aloquin’s 1st Motisha  loan (loan given to good payers) from Tujijenge Tanzania.  He hopes to get a loan to buy more cement. 

Aloquin will share this loan with his loan group   Urafiki, which totals 11 members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable in paying back the loan. 

In the picture  Aloquin is in a blue T-shirt.

loans.use: To buy more stock of cement

loans.name: C4561 Twuzuzanye Group

texts.en:
